SOLASStatus: Aqua Vista: Unknown/unspecified, AQUA VISTA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Le 7 Août 2011 à 22 h00, le navire à passagers Aqua Vista est en rade de Banyuls-sur-Mer (Pyrénées Orientale), face à la grande jetée, pour permettre à 89 touristes d’assister au feu d’artifice.

Une fois le spectacle terminé, le navire, de type catamaran en alliage léger, à vision sous-marine, fait route à 22 :32 vers Port-Vendres ce qui devra lui faire contourner le Cap Béar.

Cinq minutes plus tard, le patron confie la barre à un matelot et s’occupe de la sonorisation.

A 22 :40 hrs, l’Aqua Vista heurte violemment à 7 :5 nœuds, avec sa coque bâbord, un  récif prolongeant une ponte rocheuse située au nord de Banyuls-sur-Mer, baptisée « Cap Oullestrell » (position 42°29’53 N  /  003°08’11 E).

Les dégâts matériels sont immédiatement évalués : étrave bâbord  enfoncée, peak avant bâbord envahi ; la cloison d’abordage en revanche a résisté.

Parmi les passagers, de nombreuse personnes ont été projetées vers l’avant, certaines sont blessées plus ou moins gravement (11 blessés dont 7 seront hospitalisés pour examens ou interventions médicales).

Compte tenu des dégâts modérés, le navire reprend sa route vers Port-Vendres. 
Le patron appelle le sémaphore par téléphone à 22 :48 hrs alors qu’il double le Cap Béar.

Le CROSS Méditerranée, prévenu par le sémaphore, alerte les moyens de secours du CODIS pour l’arrivée du navire à quai vers 23 :00 hrs.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
Late on 5 August 2011, the 19m trawler Vellee suffered catastrophic flooding when on passage from Fraserburgh to Kilkeel. The crew received no warning of the water ingress from the vessel’s three high-level bilge alarms, and by the time the flood was discovered, the sea water level was above the main engine’s gearbox. The crew were unable to establish the source of the water ingress and, despite making attempts to pump out the water, in the early hours of 6 August they were forced to abandon to the liferaft.
Approximately 45 minutes later the vessel sank. The crew were rescued by helicopter and delivered safely ashore at Stornoway.

At 2225 on 05 August 2011, an able seaman (AB) fell down the staircase in the accommodation of the Maltese registered general cargo Kaie, while navigating the Skagerrak Strait.  He was given first aid by the crew members, but eventually passed away the following day. 

The investigation identified that the AB almost certainly fell down the staircase because he was under the influence of alcohol.  It was also established that the ‘no alcohol’ policy was not consistently and effectively implemented on board the ship.  The analysis of the available information suggested lack of manifestation of a safety climate on board the ship, which did not reflect the spirit of the company’s safety policy as intended to be implemented on board the ship.

Location: 3 miles northeast of Poudre d'Or Mauritius
SummaryOfEvents: The Panamanian-flagged bulk carrier ANGEL 1, sustained engine failure, subsequently dragged anchors in heavy weather, drifted and was stranded on reef, 3 miles northeast of Poudre d'Or, Mauritius on 5 August 2011 at 2224 hours (local time).  The ship sustained severe dammage to the hull.  All crew members were rescued with no injuries or pollution reported.  The ship refloated with assistance of tug CORAL SEA FOSS on 25 November 2011, however sank 40 miles off Mauritius on 26 November 2011, whilst still under tow.

MV Kadmos, a Maltese registered bulk carrier, was navigating the Malacca Strait. On 05 August 2011, a sudden impact was felt throughout the ship.
A quick look outside of the wheelhouse did not reveal any immediate cause and the first impression of the navigational officer of the watch (OOW) was that the ship had run aground.
Eventually, it was determined that Kadmos had made contact with the wreck of another vessel, which had sunk in the area during the previous week.
The investigation found that the master and the officers of the navigational watch were unaware of the wreck. Moreover the isolated danger buoy, which had been marking the site of the wreck was neither seen by the duty navigational OOW nor by the duty look-out posted on the bridge.
As a result of the actions taken by the ship’s managers, no safety recommendations have been issued.

Location: Bay of Biscay, 3 miles west of Ile de Sein, France
SummaryOfEvents: On 5 August 2011, the Belgian-flagged trawler, MARCO, with 6 crew members on board foundered after contact with a rock in the Bay of Biscay, 3 miles west of Ile de Sein, France at 0110 hrs (local time).  All 6 crew members abandoned ship to liferaft and were rescued by rescue boat SNS 060 and taken to Brest, France.  Tug ABEILLE BOURBON, oil recovery ship ARGONAUT, two trawlers and rescue boat SNS 068 attended the scene and assisted the rescue operation.  No injuries were reported.  Three oil slicks were sighted at sea.  Divers from ARGONAUT sealed the leaking fuel tanks.

Location: Arabian Sea, 25 miles southwest of Mumbai, India
SummaryOfEvents: On 4 August 2011 at 1430 hrs (local time), the Panamanian-flagged bulk carrier RAK CARRIER, in heavy weather took water in her forward holds and foundered in the Arabian Sea, 25 miles southwest of Mumbai, India.  An initial distress call was received at 0600 hrs (local time) the same day.  Eighteen crew members were rescued by INS seaking helicopter and 12 were rescued by ICGS chetak helicopter and transferred to other ships and taken to Mumbai.  INS corvette VEER, ICGS ships SAMUDRA PRAHARI, SANKALP and AMRIT KAUR and tug SMIT LUMBA attened the scene.  No injuries were reported.  Oil patches were sighted and anti-pollution measures were deployed.

A deckhand working on board the River Thames Woolwich Free Ferry, Ernest Bevin, sustained severe head injuries and drowned when he was dragged overboard by a mooring rope while releasing lines that were securing the ship to a mooring buoy. Although the casualty was wearing a lifejacket and was recovered to a workboat within minutes, waiting paramedics were unable to save the badly injured crewman.

At 05:36 hrs on 3 August 2011, the container ship Karin Schepers grounded on the Cornish coast while on passage from Cork, Ireland to Rotterdam, Netherlands. At 03:23 hrs the master relieved the second officer as the officer of the watch, and he fell asleep a short time later. No lookout was posted, and with no-one awake on the bridge, the ship continued on for over 2 hours, crossing the Land’s End Traffic Separation Scheme before grounding close to Pendeen Lighthouse, West Cornwall, England. The ship was undamaged, and the crew were able to refloat her on the rising tide.

On 01 August 2011 at approximately 17:00 hrs the unregistered MV Claire Buoyant departed Beginish Island, Co. Kerry with a crew of one on board, Skipper/Owner, five passengers and a cargo of twenty one sheep. Whilst on passage, the sheep got into difficulties and began taking water. A Mayday message was sent out on VHF Channel 16 at 18:03 hrs. Local craft came to the assistance of the crew and passengers, none suffered any injuries. All sheep were jettisoned overboard but eighteen were subsequently rescued.

On 02 August 2011, the managers of the MV Baltia notified the Maltese authorities that whilst on anchor, the vessel had reported that the master and one AB were injured during a lifeboat drill.
 
The chief mate informed the local authorities of the accident and an ambulance was dispatched on site.  Whilst the AB was discharged from hospital and ordered to rest for a period of seven days on board, the master underwent four hours of surgery on 04 August 2011.  As a result of the accident, he sustained three fractured vertebrae.
 
The evidence was collected over two deployments.  The analysis found that the lifeboat was almost certainly released by the crew members inside from a considerable height.  It also found that there was a communication barrier between the chief mate and the master inside the lifeboat.

1.	The Philippine Coast Guard reported that on or about 1800H, 30 July 2011, MV “ASIA MALAYSIA” departed Cebu Port, Philippines bound for Iloilo City, Philippines.  There were 134 passengers and 44 crews on-board.  The weather condition at that time was moderate.

2.	Based on the Marine Protest executed by the Master of the vessel MV “ASIA MALAYSIA”, it was on or about 0350H, 31 July 2011 while navigating in the vicinity of Payong Point, the vessel encountered big waves and started to list 5 degrees to its starboard side.  The Master ordered ballasting and deballasting to stabilize the vessel but it turned futile.  The listing continued and increased to 20 degrees.  Eventually, the cargoes shifted towards the starboard side. 

3.	Thevessel changed course and made a distressed call to the Philippine Coast Guard. Passengers were assisted in donning life jackets in preparation for abandon ship.

4.	On or about 0420H, the Master ordered to slacken speed and change course from 210°.

5.	On or about 0440H at Latitude 11°01.64 North Longitude 123°02.02 East within the vicinity of Calabazas Island, Ajuy, Iloilo, Philippines, the main engine was stopped.  The listing of the vessel increased to 25°.  It was then reported that water reached the level of the side door and ingress of water flowed into the engine room.

6.	On or about 0530H, inflatable life rafts were launch.  Passengers were transferred to MV “Filipinas Cebu” and MT “Fil Visayas, the vessels which immediately responded to the said incident.

7.	On or about 0620H, all of the passengers were safely transported to the responding vessel while all officers and crew of MV “ASIA MALAYSIA” stayed on-board.  

8.	On or about 0800H at the vicinity of Calabazas Island, Ajuy, Iloilo, Philippines, MV “ASIA MALAYSIA” slowly sank.  The officers and crew abandoned the ship on time.

9.	There were no casualties reported. All 134 passengers and 44 crews were rescued in the said incident.

The Vega Rose was departing from Donghaeport with a pilot on board when, due to thick fog, it contacted the inner wall of the northern seawall at 0532h on July 30, 2011. 
Due to this accident the shell plating of the Vega Rose on the portside bow was badly bent and had a puncture with a diameter of about 5 cm. The northern seawall of Donghae port suffered damage to the fixedconcrete and casing of the inside wall for a property damage of about KRW 30 million.

At 2230 hours (Malaysia Local Time) on 29th July 2011, MV Xin Tai Hai and MV B Oceania involve in collision in Malacca Strait Traffic Separation Scheme South East Bound Lane off Pulau Pisang, Malaysia. MV B Oceania sink due to collision.

All MV B Oceania ship crew were rescued by MV Ikuara and landed safely at Singapore. MV Xin Tai Hai which sustained minor damage to her port side hull anchored off Pulau Kukup, Malaysia.

SOLASStatus: Seute Deern: Unknown/unspecified, SEUTE DEERN: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At 15 :10 hrs on 28 July 2011, four people were injured on the traditional ship SEUTE DEERN while weighing the anchor east of Christianso near Bornholm when the cranks of the manual winch turned back out of control and the anchor chain ran out.
Two physicians who were also on board rendered first aid. The Seute Deern hoisted anchor and headed for Nexo, an emergency physician and paramedic, who had previously been lowered onto a rescue cruiser by a SAR helicopter to a hospital in Copenhagen. The other two casualties could be treated in Ronne on Bornholm. A WNW wind with a force of 3 Bft prevailed at the time of the accident and the wave height was 1.5 m. One of the anchor’s flukes broke during hoisting and was lost.

On July 28,2011 oil tanker(bunker barge) DMITRIJS maneuvered in the area of Riga shipyard between piers RKR-6 and JM- 26.At 11.46 LT to reduce the momentum forward, captain shifted the remote propeller pitch controler into position astern. At 11.48 reversing ahead to proceed towards pier JM-26, the hydraulic transmission failed to respond (stuck of Pilot valve) and the vessel increasing momentum backwards began turning towards pier RKR-6 where dredger MARIEKE was securely moored. At 11.49 starbord anchor was used to slow movement backwards. At 11.50 was impact with MARIEKE resulting in deformation of the frame and hull plates on her port side (Class subject). As from captains report the speed was about 2,5 knots backwards at the moment of impact.DMITRIJS suffered minor damage to her aft part without the capasity loss.

Location: Garden reach, Hugli River, W. Bengal, India

SummaryOfEvents: Turkish registered passenger ship IHSAN ALYANAK sustained steering failure and struck the breakwater on leaving Konak Pier, Izmir, Turkey at 1150 hrs on 25 July 2011.  She sustained damage to starboard forward hull, took water and sank at berth.  No injuries were reported; passengers disembarked at the pier.  Some oil pollution was reported at sea.  Anti-pollution measures were deployed.

InitialEvent: Derailment of the hatch-lid gantry crane
SummaryOfEvents: On 22 July 2011, the hatch-lid gantry crane on board the dry cargo ship Blue Note derailed while it was carrying a single hatch-lid to its stowed position in preparation for discharging cargo. The derailment caused the chief officer, who had been riding on one of the crane’s wheel units, to be thrown overboard ; an able seaman, who had been riding on another wheel unit, to be left hanging by his hands over 8:4m deep hold; and the second officer, who was operating the crane, to fall the deck of the control platform. All three crewmen were lucky to escape with only minor injuries.

The vessel departed from Bassen 433, Port of  Bordeaux at 1215 hours on 21 July 2011 loaded with a  
cargo of bulk Iron Oxide (2, 238.056 mt.)

A pilot assisted in navigation down the Gironde river disembarking from the vessel at 1545 hours close to Buoy 13A. The Master then piloted the vessel under assistance from shore radar until the Fairway buoy was reached. At this time he set an initial course of 300 degrees and was bound for Rotterdam. 

             Conditions were said to be;
             Wind – West 20 knots        Ship said to be rolling gently about 5 degrees either way.
             No pitching was experienced and a speed of 8.8 knots was maintained.

At about 2330 hours the Master observed the vessel develop a starboard list of 5-7 degrees., a list 
which gradually increased until at 2345 hours, having had the ballast tanks and bilges checked for 
water, the Master realised that the cargo may have shifted. The Master then put the wheel to 
starboard which resulted in the vessel becoming upright before falling over to port. At this time he fully realised that the cargo was shifting and causing a free-surface effect.
The vessel was then brought round onto a course of 120 degrees the intention being to head back 
towards Bordeaux.
At 0115 hours on 22 July 2001 VHF contact was made with the Bordeaux pilot station and they were 
advised of the vessel’s problem and their assistance was requested. However, the vessel’s condition 
became uncontrollable and the list increased to an estimated 35 degrees.
The crew had all been advised of the problem and they were assembled and, when the vessel was 
stopped, launched the liferaft in preparation for possible abandonment of the vessel.
At this time, approximately 0200 hours the Master sent out a MAYDAY call on VHF 16.  A shore station acknowledged the call and advised that a rescue helicopter would be in 15 minutes to uplift the crew. A vessel in the vicinity, Arklow Fen also responded and was heading for the stricken vessel.
The Master and crew were subsequently uplifted by a helicopter from the Bordeaux Rescue Centre.
The vessel was abandoned in a position 17.8 nm x 120 degrees from the fairway buoy.

Later that day a salvage tug the “Abeille Langedoc” was dispatched to render assistance arriving on              scene at 1300 hours. A second tug “Boluda” was sent to assist with salvage operations. The  Master and Chief Engineer were also taken onboard to assist in the operation. An oil spill was observed              in the vicinity. It was also reported that the list had increased to 60 degrees.
The tug “Abeille Langedoc” and another vessel “VB Oleron” made fast to the vessel and commenced towing the ‘Union Neptune’ towards La Rochelle.
At 1833 hours it was advised that the vessel had listed further and was in danger of sinking. At              1900 hours approximately it was reported that the vessel had sunk.

On the afternoon of 22 July 2011 an aircraft flew over the location and observed the vessel still to be showing a small section of bow above the surface. Photographs show that this was the case.
 It was stated that the depth of water was 35 metres however, the vessel itself is over 87 metres in length therefore it may be presumed the vessel’s stern could possibly be on the bottom. This, as reported, constitutes a hazard to navigation.

Owners/operators are apparently currently engaged with salvors.

At about 1246 on 21 July 2011, a shipyard worker sustained fatal injuries on board the Maltese registered general cargo Algarve, while the vessel was in dry-dock.  His corpse was removed from the emergency fire pump space about four hours later.  He was declared dead on the scene of the accident. 

Although a safety investigator was deployed to the accident site and assisted by the crew members and owners representatives, the safety investigation was hampered during the collection of evidence and could not come to a clear conclusion as to what could have caused the fire inside the space. 
 
The hypotheses on the cause of the fire were built around the acetylene torch and/or hoses which were inside the space.  Whilst it could not be ascertained as to what had started the fire, it was possible that the fire started as a result of acetylene leakage coming in contact with an ignition source, oxygen coming in direct contact with oil and grease, or oxygen enrichment inside the emergency fire pump space.

SOLASStatus: Jean Ricciardi: Unknown/unspecified, JEAN RICCIARDI: Unknown/unspecified
Location: 0.5 miles west of the breakwater at Sete, France
SummaryOfEvents: On 19 July 2011, at 0614 hrs (local time), French-registered fishing vessel JEAN RICCIARDI sustained engine failure and stranded 0.5 miles west of the breakwater at Sete, France.  Two crew members abandoned ship to the liferaft and were rescued by a pilot boat. The captain remined on board. The fishing vessel sustained damage to port hull plating and took water.  She was refloated with the assistance from lifeboat SNS 062 and towed to harbour, however, the ingress of water could not be contained and she foundered at 0900 hrs later the same day in 17 metres of water.  The captain was rescued by the local emergency services. No injuries were reported.  The wreck was refloated on 14 September 2011 and towed to Sete.

During berthing operation at Visakhapatnam Port, India, the vessel touched bottom when it passed the port channel. In the course of touching bottom, the vessel sustained considerable damage to the shell plating. The vessel soon thereafter proceeded to Singapore for repairs to be made on the vessel.

SOLASStatus: APOSTOLOS D: SOLAS, GOLDEN SHUI: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: While transiting the Singapore Straite, the Master of APOSTOLOS D observed another vessel, RYUJIN, approaching from APOSTOLOS D's port bow. The APOSTOLOS D Master also observed another vessel, GOLDEN SHUI, anchored near the pilot boarding ground. The Master tried to contact RYUJIN via radio and even attempted light signals and sound signals in an attempt to learn RYUJIN's intentions. In attempting to avoid the collision and steer clear of RYUJIN, APOSTOLOS D's engine was stopped and was then ordered full astern. Unfortunately, the strong currents drifted APOSTOLOS D towards GOLDEN SHUI and APOSTOLOS D eventually collided into GOLDEN SHUI.

On 18 July 2011, the Panamanian-flagged stern trawler LOLO foundered whilst moored at Cadiz, Spain.  No injuries or pollution were reported.  The vessel was refloated and towed to El Puerto de Santa Maria, Spain for breaking up.

InitialEvent: Fatal accident of a stevedore during loading operation
SummaryOfEvents: While loading pipes on the general cargo ship YUSHO SEVEN alongside with berth R of Port Island, a stevedore was crushed under the pipes because of the cargo shifting.

On 19 July 2011, the Harbour Master of La Spezia, Italy, notified the Maltese authorities that on 17 July 2011, a report was received  that the motor yacht Lady Luck had reported flooding in her aft compartment.  It was stated that following an assessment of the situation, the master decided to return to the port without any shore assistance.  The yacht was not in danger of sinking, however, as a result of the flooding, she sustained electrical and mechanical damages to several of the fitted components on board.

On 17 July 2011, at about 0400, the Accident Investigation Board of Norway notified the Marine Safety Investigation Unit that at about 0205(LT), CSL Trimnes had run aground. 

Preliminary information indicated that the vessel’s course had remained unaltered for several miles before she ran aground. 

After carrying out the relevant inspections, and in agreement with the Norwegian authorities, the refloating operations were commenced.  Eventually, the vessel was successfully refloated on the same day under her own power and with the assistance of a rescue craft and one tugboat. 

The vessel proceeded to Roervik anchorage, escorted by the rescue craft and the tugboat, where she dropped her anchor for a thorough inspection of the bottom shell plating. 

The investigation found that the duty navigational officer of the watch (OOW) fell asleep on the bridge and the course was not altered at a planned waypoint.  It also identified (symbolic) barriers, whose status at the time did not prevent the grounding from happening. 

On the basis of the actions taken by the new managers of the ship, recommendations were only issued to the previous managers.

SOLASStatus: Fremantle Express: Unknown/unspecified, FREMANTLE EXPRESS: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 15 July 2011, Fremantle Express, a UK-registered container ship was berthing in the port of Veracruz when a headline parted under tension. The broken mooring line recoiled and struck an ordinary seaman (OS) who was standing on the forecastle. The seaman died of his injuries. The ship was moving astern along her berth at the time of the accident, assisted by two tugs.

After receiving the report, Lianyungang marine rescue centre deployed the rescue vessel DONG HAI JIU 111 to the scene to conduct search and rescue. After arriving in the area the sunken vessel was identified as the Chinese flagged bulker XIN CHEN HUI 9, 2967 GT, length 97 meters, 15.8 meters wide. The vessel was proceeding from Fuzhou to Tianjin with a crew of 11 persons. At 0300, Jul. 14, Cosco Fukuyama successfully rescued three of the crew from the water.

A seafarer died in a work related accident on board the vessel Delia at sea while on passage. 
The vessel was partly loaded with swarf (shredded steel turnings) on her way from Odense/Denmark to El Ferrol /Spain. The seafarer died due to oxygen deficiency after having entered into an enclosed space adjacent to the forecastle bosun store. Sent forward by the bosun to fetch tools for the work being conducted on the accommodation deck, the seafarer entered the enclosed space between fore peak stores and cargo hold which was loaded with dangerous goods as per the international dangerous goods code.
Not returning to his work station on the vessels stern, a fellow deck crew commenced searching. Finding the cargo hold front access open, the search was now concentrated on the forward enclosed space, which is connected atmosphere wise to the cargo hold. There, on the double bottom, the seafarer was found unconscious without signs of respiration or pulse.

Location: Off Honmoku wharf, Yokohama city, Kanagawa Pref.
SummaryOfEvents: General cargo ship AQUAMARINE, which was proceeding from Ohgi-shima toward Philippines, was in collision with fishing vessel HIRASHIN-MARU off Honmoku wharf. HIRASHIN-MARU consequently capsized.

On July 5th, 2011, Liberian flagged M/T BRILLANTE VIRTUOSO was boarded by armed pirates disguised as military officials while drifting 12nm from Aden, Yemen. M/T BRILLANTE VIRTUOSO experienced main engine failure and suddenly stopped. Infuriated by this, the pirates began shooting in the Engine Room causing a fire that rapidly spread to the accommodation area. Despite the damage sustained by M/T BRILLANTE VIRTUOSO there were no injuries or pollution incidents reported.

Rescue boat and a navy helicopter rescued 21 passengers when the captain made an emergency call for help, but 23 people were reported still missing.  The boat was found around 87 miles south of San Felipe.

SummaryOfEvents: Vessel get fire at 21:00 on 01/07/2011, docked in private port. Loaded with 2000 wooden lobster traps. Fire controlled by local fire department, Crew was not onboard.

The chemical tanker Nisshomaru was sailing in the North Fairway in Port of Nagoya with 5 crew members on board consisting of the master, chief engineer, chief officer, first engineer, and junior chief officer after leaving the quay of the cargo owner in Port of Nagoya where she unloaded sodium hydrogen sulfide. On 28 June 2011 at 0410 Pacific Daylight Time, while under tow of the tug F.W. Wright, the loaded gravel barge Empire 40 struck the Queensborough Railway Bridge in the Fraser River, British Columbia. The bridge centre swing span and protection pier sustained extensive damage. This resulted in the bridge being inoperable for a period of 2 months after the striking, causing major disruptions to railway and river traffic. No one was injured and there was no pollution as a result of this occurrence.

On the 26th of June MV “FRANK W”, underway from Ijmuiden, Netherlands to Halmstad, Sweden, collided with a local Danish fishing vessel LILLY E 2, which consequently sunk.
The fishing vessels crew was saved by the local pilot boat “SKAWPILOT 2”.
The MV “FRANK W”, under the navigational watch of its master, as stand on vessel sighted the fishing vessel crossing from port side to late, making its last moment manoeuvre insufficient. The fact that the fishing vessel showed no reaction to the situation allows the assumption that the bridge was obviously not manned.

On 25 June 2011, the general cargo ship Saffier made contact with the tug Svitzer Ferriby, which was berthed at Quay 5 and was unmanned, when control of its controllable  pitch propeller (CPP) system was lost while berthing in the port of Immingham. Saffier’s stern was breached above the waterline at the starboard quarter, and the tug suffered minor damage.

Fire broke out in the engine room of the cargo ship “MAYSORA” in position 39 51N  025 51E in the Eastern Aegean, while enroute from the Suez Canal to the Turkish northwestern province of  Tekirdag. The vessel had a crew of 73 on board with 73,500 livestock.
The fire started at 2350hrs 22nd May 2011 in the either from electrician store or the  electrician work shop due to an electrical short circuit.

Vessel proceeded to a safe anchorage in order to fight the fire.  At about 0100 hrs the Engine Room CO2 system was activated.

The fire was successfully extinguished by ship’s staff and engine room deemed safe at 0500hrs. The vessel was subsequently towed to the port of Martas, arriving on 25th May 2010.

No crew members were injured or there was no pollution

SOLASStatus: ABUELA MARIANA: Unknown/unspecified, SIGAS ETTRICK: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On the 22nd June 2011 at 03:24 GMT Maltese LPG tanker SIGAS ETTRICK collided with Spanish fishing vessel on duty ABUELA MARIANA 20' off the coast of Huelva (Spain) resulting in minor damages for both vessels. The main cause of the accident was that the fishing vessel ABUELA MARIANA, as a vessel in navigation, did not move away from the course of the LPG tanker SIGAS ETTRICK. The most likely reason for the collision was that there wasn't anyone on the bridge of the fishing vessel attending navigation until the collision occurred. The first officer of the ship SIGAS ETTRICK did not value the possibility of the collision , having the false perception that in the end it would be the fishing vessel which would carry out the maneuver to avoid the collision.

SOLASStatus: CCNI RIMAC: Unknown/unspecified, CSAV PETORCA: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On June 21, 2011 at approximately 1154 LT, Liberian flagged container ship, CSAV PETORCA  was involved in a collision with German flagged vessel, CCNI RIMAC at Yangshan Port, Shanghai, China The CSAV PETORCA was transiting from Ningbo to Shanghai, China under heavy fog conditions and poor visibility. The vessel stopped to pick up a pilot; the pilot advised the vessel to keep north of the fairway channel. The Master of the CSAV PETORCA decided to move the vessel to the south of the fairway. CSAV PETORCA observed CCNI RIMAC on her radar and noted that the CCNI RIMAC had altered her course suddenly to starboard. The Master of the CSAV PETORCA moved the vessel hard to port and gave the order to stop the engines; despite these attempts, the CSAV PETORCA and CCNI RIMAC collided.

The vessel was berthing alongside a ship in China for repaor.  The Chief Officer on board the vessel was killed by a derrick boom which swung towards him when he pressed the start button to start the hydraulic pump for the hydraulic system.

Le 19 juin 2011, en fin de matinée, le S/Y Allures appareille du mouillage de Punta Mortella pour une courte navigation à l’ouvert du Golfe de Saint-Florent (Haute-Corse). Le programme initial, qui prévoyait une navigation à destination de l’Ile Rousse, a été modifié par le capitaine, au vu des conditions météo, afin que le séjour reste suffisamment confortable pour les huit clients qui sont à bord.
Les conditions météo au large sont cependant maniables pour un navire de la taille d’ Allures et un équipage composé de professionnels. Après l’appareillage, Allures fait route au près bon plein, sous 2 ris et génois partiellement déroulé. Le flybridge est occupé par quatre personnes : le capitaine, au poste de barre tribord, le second et une hôtesse-marin, tous deux occupés à lover et ranger les drisses, et une cliente, sur bâbord. Les autres clients et membres d’équipage sont sur le pont principal. Le navire est encore relativement protégé par la côte et le vent est régulier, établi à 30 noeuds au 280°, les vagues de 1,50 mètre à 2 mètres. La vitesse est de 12,6 noeuds.
Peu après, alors que le capitaine contrôle le réglage des voiles et la tension dans les haubans (à partir d’un écran multifonctions du poste de barre), un violent craquement se fait entendre, instantanément suivi de la chute du mât dans l’eau, et de la bôme sur le flybridge. Le capitaine est prisonnier sous la voile mais se dégage rapidement pour évaluer la situation : le second, qui se tenait appuyé au caisson tribord, à proximité du poste de barre, est mortellement blessé par la bôme. La cliente et l’hôtesse-marin, toutes deux sur bâbord, ne sont pas blessées. Immédiatement, l’équipage prend en charge les clients pour éviter toute panique et les garder en sécurité. Au vu de la situation, le capitaine lance un Mayday qui sera relayé par un motor yacht vers le CROSS Méditerranée Corse.
En début d’après-midi, Allures sera remorqué jusqu’à un mouillage abrité, et les clients débarqués sains et saufs.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

The chief of the skiff boat died as a result of the injuries he sustained.

SummaryOfEvents:
At 00:36 hrs on 18 June 2011, the skipper of the yacht Lion fell overboard and drowned while still attached to the yacht by means of a tether connected to his lifejacket harness.


It took the crew 16 minutes to recover the skipper to the deck, where he was pronounced dead bu a consultant cardiologist who was one of the crew.

On the morning of 14 June 2011, the 11.9m potting ship About Time was proceeding towards Milford Haven from her fishing grounds. At some time between 06:39 and 07:31, on of the ship’s deckhands, was lost overboard. The accident was not seen by any of the other members of the ship’s crew and the fact that he was missing was not discovered until 08:12. Despite an extensive air and sea search, he was not found.

InitialEvent: Break and Lost of a towline
SummaryOfEvents:
On 11 June 2011 at 13:00 hrs, While on voyage, the tug Seabulk Plover towline parted. Approximately 210 metres of towline was lost with MV Wisdom (which was towed by Seabulk Plover) which started drifting in a direction of approximately 080° at an approximate speed of 3 knots. The master reported the matter to WTMS and his owners. 
At 13:20 hrs, Seabulk Plover picked up remainder of her towline but, due to bad visibility and stormy weather, could not catch the messenger of emergency towline. Both ships were rolling heavily. At 18:30 hrs, the coast Guard ordered the ship to enter Mumbai anchorage. At Coast Guard ordered the ship to drop anchor. (Position – Latitude 19° 01.8’N, Longitude 072°40.0’E).
On 12 June 2011, at 08:40 hrs, the tow Wisdom ran aground at Latitude 19° 05.8’N and Longitude 072° 48.5’E. The sea bottom was soft mud. At 09:35 hrs, the Coast Guard ordered the tug to proceed to the Pilot Station. At 14:40 hrs, the tug dropped her starboard anchor at position: Latitude 18° 52.0’N, Longitude 072° 51.6’E.

At about 1246 on 11 June 2011, the 21.3 m long tug Adonis capsized and sank during an operation to tow a water barge within Gladstone harbour. Three of the people on board were able to swim clear of the overturned tug, however a forth man was not able to escape from the tug's wheelhouse. Police divers recovered his body the following day.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Italian-flagged passenger ship BELUO sank after striking the formiche rocks 1 mile southeast of Ponza, Italy on 8 June 2011 at 2330 hours.  All 4 crew members were rescued by the coastguard with no injuries or pollution reported.

At 2321 on 1 June 2011, the privately owned rigid-hulled inflatable boat Morfil collided with the passenger ferry Sun Clipper by Blackfriars Road Bridge on the River Thames, London. The vessels were travelling in opposite directions. On impact, Morfil's two crew were pitched into the water but were quickly rescued by the local inshore lifeboat; both were shocked but uninjured. Morfil eventually grounded under the road bridge and was a constructive total loss. Damage to Sun Clipper was only superficial and there was no pollution.
The investigation identified several factors contributing to this accident, including:
"	Morfil's coxswain was under the influence of alcohol and did not take action to avoid Sun Clipper until between 1 and 2 seconds before the collision.
"	The action taken by Sun Clipper's master to avoid the collision was limited by the proximity of the road bridge and mooring buoys.
"	Refurbishment works under the Blackfriars Road Bridge resulted in both vessels using the same bridge arch and their skippers not being able to see each other until about 10 seconds before the collision.
"	Morfil's speed was significantly greater than the 12 knot limit recommended by the Port of London Authority.
"	Morfil's coxswain had limited knowledge and experience of navigating on the River Thames and was unaware of, or ignored, the local regulations and advice.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

Location: sea of Okhotsk, 75 miles northeast of Cape Terpenia, Sakhalin, the Russian Federation
SummaryOfEvents:
On 1 June 2011 at 11:55 hours, the fishing vessel FINIST capsized after taking water in the sea of Okhotsk, 75 miles northeast of Cape Terpenia, Sakhalin, the Russian Federation.

No casualties were reported; all 14 crew members were rescued by border patrol vessel No. 704 ARGAL.  Some oil pollution was reported.  FINIST was last reported adrift on 10 June 2011 and later presumed to have subsequently sunk.

On 28 Mai 2011, a 23 year old crew member on board the commercially operated sailing yacht Liquid Vortex was seriously injured when the ship gybed. The gybe occurred when the yatch was running downwind in the Mith of Malham offshore race in the English Channel.

The crew member was at the helm when she was knocked to the deck by the mainsheet. She sustained head and spinal injuries and was evacuated by helicopter to Plymouth, England were she was hospitalised for 2 months.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
Le 26 Mai 2011 au matin, le caseyeur Stessary, mis à l’eau à partir d’une remorque, quitte la plage de Pirou pour se rendre sur ses lieux de pêche.

Il y relève ses filières de casiers et retourne à terre avec une pêche de 120 kilos de crabes rangés  dans des caisses en pontée.

Le vent est de secteur ouest de plus de 25 nœuds, la houle est formée et à l’approche de la côte la mer est difficile et tend à déferler du fait de la remontée des fonds.

Vers 9 heures, alors qu’il passe sur un haut fond, le Stessary est retourné par une déferlante.

L’équipage de 3 personnes se retrouve à l’eau. L’un des matelots et le patron ont la vie sauve, l’autre matelot disparait et son corps n’est pas retrouvé malgré les recherches.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
The ro-ro passenger ship Skåne carried both passengers and ro-ro cargo between Trelleborg and Rostock two to three times daily. According to the timetable each port stay was approximately one and a half hour. This made cargo operations intense in order to finish in time. In Trelleborg, the cargo was unloaded through two openings in the stern of the vessel, one on deck 3 and one on deck 5, connected to ramps on the quayside.
On the 25th of May 2011 at 21.00, the vessel berthed at quay berth 9 in the port of Trelleborg. Shortly after arrival the passengers disembarked and the unloading of the cargo, consisting of cars, trucks and trailers, commenced. The chief officer who was in charge of the cargo handling was standing on the ramp at deck three preparing for the loading. At the same time the last trailer was about to be unloaded with a terminal tractor (tug master). At 21.15 the trailer was reversed out from the ship and onto the ramp. When reversing, the driver of the terminal tractor did not have a view over the area behind the trailer. Therefore the driver stopped and when he saw that the chief officer waved at him to continue he backed out on the ramp. Suddenly a person from ashore rushed towards the terminal tractor and waved to the driver to stop.
As the driver stopped and stepped out of the vehicle he saw the chief officer lying on the ground face down between the back wheels of the terminal tractor. He immediately called for help and the rescue service was alerted. The chief officer had been hit by the back of the trailer, fell between its wheels and then had been dragged along the ground by the terminal tractor for approximately ten meters. As a result he sustained serious injuries and was taken to hospital.

On 24 May 2011, Seatruck Ferries Limited’s ro-ro cargo ferry, Clipper Point, made heavy contact with the quay, two ro-ro ferries and another ship while manoeuvring to berth stern-first at the Port of Heysham’s N°1 linkspan. Clipper Point sustained damage to her starboard quarter and her steering compartment was holed below the waterline.

During a scheduled arrival into the port, the wind increased to 34 knots and the ship was set closer to the port’s South Quay than was intended. After Clipper Point narrowly missed one of two ships that were alongside South Quay, the master attempted to turn the ship to port in his usual manner; however, the ship was out of position and only one of the ship’s tow bow thrusters was operational. At 05:16 hrs the starboard quarter of Clipper Point made contact with South Quay, holing the ship below the waterline. The tug skipper, who had been standing by in his ship to assist Clipper Point conduct the turn, decided not to engage his tug due to the risk of damage to his own ship. Clipper Point’s master persevered with the turn and the ship subsequently made contact with two other ro-ro ferries that were berthed at N°. 2 and N°3 linkspans before it was finally secured at N°1 linkspan.

On 23 May 2011, the products Tanker from the Federation of Russia foundered while undergoing repairs at illichevsk shipyard, Illichevsk, Ukraine at 1200 hrs (local time).  No injuries were reported.  Some pollution was reported.  Anti-pollution boom was deployed.

On 21 May 2011, at approximately 1255 Atlantic Daylight Time and one-half mile off Cap du Phare, Îles-de-la-Madeleine, Quebec, the small fishing vessel Lady Jacqueline took on water and was abandoned with a load of lobster on board. The operator and the 2 crew members were rescued by fishing vessels from l’Étang-du-Nord. The crew exhibited symptoms of mild hypothermia; none of them were injured.

SummaryOfEvents:
At 10:04 hrs, on 15 May 2011, the UK registered container ship CMA CGM Platon made heavy contact with a quay on the south bank of the River Thames. The quay sustained superficial damage but the ship suffered significant damage to her bow and her forepeak tank was punctured. Fortunately there was no pollution and no one was hurt.

CMA CGM Platon had sailed from a berth at the Northfleet Hope Container Terminal at Tilbury at 09:58 hrs. The pilot had conducted the manoeuvre, under similar tidal conditions, on a number of occasions without incident.

MT Box arrived offshore Cotonou on 13 May 2011 at 1900 for discharging her part cargo through an STS transfer operation to MT Dani-1.
STS operations were eventually postponed by several hours  due to unfavourable weather conditions.  They were eventually commenced at 1400 on 14 May.  MT Box was the constant heading ship during the mooring operations and she was maintaining a 1800 heading with 2.5 knots speed as ordered by the mooring master who was on board the MT Dani-1 i.e. the manoeuvring ship.  The manoeuvring ship was approaching MT Box from her starboard quarter.
The manoeuvring ship, however, on closer approach, could not parallel the course of MT Box properly and eventually made contact.  Both vessels sustained damages to their respective hulls although no injuries or pollution were reported.

SummaryOfEvents: On May 14, 2011 at approximately 0335 LT, Liberian flagged container ship, TS SINGAPORE collided by Isle of Man vessel, MCC JAKARTA in the TSS of the East Lama Channel (Lat: 22 09.30N Long: 114 12.40E). After TS SINGAPORE had completed its cargo operation in Hong Kong, the vessel joined the Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS) in the East Lama Channel. TS SINGAPORE observed two vessels, the XIN NAN TAI 77 and the MCC JAKARTA from her port bow. SummaryOfEvents: On May 13, 2011 at approximately 0400LT, the Liberian flagged container vessel, CSAV PIRQUE (IMO#  9215842)  was involved in a collision with the Liberian flagged container vessel, GENIUS I (IMO # 8200137). The CSAV PIRQUE was transiting from Shanghai, China to Pusan, South Korea when the collision occurred in the Zhoushan Area of the East China Sea (Lat: 30 36N Long: 123 00E). The CSAV PIRQUE was in the position of stand-on vessel, while the GENIUS I was to be the giving way vessel. The GENIUS I, however, collided with the CSAV PIRQUE on her port side. As a result of the collision, the CSAV PIRQUE sustained damage to cargo Hold No. 5, the ballast tank, and the port side bulkhead; nine containers fell overboard and twenty-one containers on board were damaged. Location: 52.5 nm West of Achill Beg Island, Achill Co. Mayo
SummaryOfEvents: On 10 May 2011, approximately 52.5 nm west of Achill Beg Island, Achill, Co. Mayo, the fishing vessel MARK AMAY II hauled its nets and was preparing to shoot them again.  The four crew members were positioned on deck, two on either side of the trawl deck aft, each pair responsible for one net.  The skipper was in the wheelhouse, at the winch controls and watching through the aft window.  The port net ran out smoothly, however the starboard net became snagged.  As one of the crew members crossed over the port net on his way to the rail, he stumbled and lost his footing as the port net was running out and carried him overboard with it.  With the motion of the vessel the crew member was being alternatively pulled under the stern of the boat and pushed back out behind.  It is possible that the stern of the vessel came down on top of him and struck him on the head rendering him unconscious, as he released his grip on the net and stopped moving.  The skipper, realising what was happening, stopped the vessel immediately.  As soon as he saw the crew member floating out from under the vessel, he started to bring the boat around.  The life raft was inflated and the crew member was pulled into the raft.  CPR was administered for 15 minutes, while a ‘Mayday’ call by VHF, giving details of the vessels position was sent, however the call was not answered.   At 10:26 hrs the Malin Head Coast Guard was raised on the radio.  At 12:09 hrs, the MRSC helicopter R118 arrived at the scene; the injured crew member was lifted off and winched aboard the helicopter and taken to a waiting ambulance at Sligo Airport where he was pronounced dead.

Shortly after 0400 Pacific Daylight Time on 09 May 2011, a fire broke out in the engine room of the small fishing vessel Neptune II. After their attempt to fight the fire was unsuccessful, the 2 crew members abandoned the vessel into their dive tender and issued a distress call. Neptune II burned to the waterline and subsequently sank east of the Broken Islands in Johnstone Strait, British Columbia. There were no injuries.

A Faroe Islands stern trawler, ATHENA, caught fire while undergoing repairs at Runavik, Faroe Islands on 9 May 2011 at 0001 hours (local time).  Local fire services and coastguard ships BRIMIL and TJALDRID assisted with fire fighting operations.  Three crew members were rescued.  The trawler was completely damaged beyond repair.
A group of Anglers went fishing on 8 May 2011 on Lough Mask in two boats. One boat was swamped in bad weather and capsized. One man tragically drowned.

The cargo M/V CHANGHAI 26, en route to Mazu wiht 9 crew members on board, struck rocks amid low visibility and sank near Dongyn Island in the Taiwan Strait on May 8. Nine sailors fell into the sea. The maritime rescue authority in Mazu conducted a search and rescue operation.

While Liberian flagged oil tanker, CE NIRIIS was transiting the Mediterranean Sea, about 35 nm from the coast of Tunisia, Italian flagged fishing boat, FENICE, approached CE NIRIIS from the latte vessel's port side. South of Horns a leakage in the engine room was discovered. Attempts to discharge the water from the engine room failed. 
Approximately one and a half hours after the discovery of the leakage the ship foundered. Just before the foundering the skipper his life raft and was shortly after saved by the ship with whom he had been trawling in pair with.

The same day, at 00.18 a.m., m/v. TIGULLIO, a 5366 G.R.T. Italian flaggered and registered tanker, was leaving the port of Falconara Marittima,  bound to Pescara (Middle Adriatic Sea) 
Her course was 156° and speed was about 12 knts.
At 05.05 a.m., she collided with “Falco  Pescatore” in position 43°11’.64 N - 014°09’.00 E at about 14 miles off the coast of Porto S. Giorgio.

When navigating towards the port of Singapore, at about 0800hours LT on 27th of May 2011, it was found that 3rd Officer was missing (investigation revealed that the he had been sighted on the ship till 0045 hours LT on 27th of May 2011). The ship immediately raised the alarm and reversed course to search for the missing crew by all members of the crew, also requesting the related organization, RCC Australia for assistance in the search.  The search was conducted at sea using assisting vessel and Search and Rescue Aircraft from RCC Australia. A thorough search onboard the ship was also conducted. The search was continued with RCC aircraft on 27th May 2011 and till sunset, 1815 LT on the 28th of May 2011. Thereafter the search was continued by the ship till 0025LT hours on 29th May 2011, but the missing 3rd Officer  could not be found. 
Thereafter there was no choice but to abandon the search and the ship resumed navigation towards Singapore Port. Thus the ship was deviated due to a missing crew. I hereby affirm the correctness of the above statement.

At 0930 on 22nd April 2011 a the re-supply vessel Grampian Defender was called in by the BP Magnus offshore  platform to provide close standby support. During its approach to a holding position, outside the installations 500m zone, where it intended to undertake, a full pre-entry systems check there was an apparent loss of the functionality of the ships manoeuvring equipment. The vessel entered the 500m zone without stopping and impacted the platform's jacket, resulting in minor structural damage to the installation and damage to the vessel.
Control of the vessel was regained and she moved away from the installation using her stern thruster and carried out a damage assessment. There was some water ingress which was initially controlled by the vessels pumps and later stopped indicating damage to the Port Azimuth, and hull plating damage, but the integrity of the hull appeared not to have been compromised.

At 13.37 the vessel was released from the field to proceed to back port to be dry docked. There were no injuries or environmental damage.

The subsequent investigation found that the master had tested both the forward and stern thrusters at the aft control position before transferring control to the forward panel.  At this point it appears he selected auto-pilot.  At 700 m from the platform he eased power to "slow" but this had no effect.  He then de-clutched the forward thruster to reduce speed and set the control to full astern but the stern thruster did not respond, indeed the speed was reported to have increased. A short time later a blackout occurred as the increased load on the generators resulted in a cascade failure as the speed droop resulted in low frequency tripping of the units.

The vessel was fitted with an unusual control configuration.  When in manual control the thrusters were controlled in heading by a rotating joystick which incorporated a lever controlling the propeller revs.  When the master rotated the joystick, the thruster did not rotate as it was still being controlled by the auto-pilot.  The master applied increased propeller revs expecting the resultant thrust to stop the vessel.  This in fact increased the vessel¿s speed in the direction controlled by the auto-pilot and caused the contact. 

The master was unfamiliar with the propulsion control system and the company¿s induction procedures were not comprehensive enough to provide a proper system familiarisation. The master was unaware that he had left the thrusters under the control of the auto-pilot.

The US and Japanese Coastguard ships and aircraft proceeded to the scene.  At 1945 hrs (Japan standard time) all crew members abandoned ship to liferafts due to the severity of the fire and subsequent explosions.  The crew were taken to Solomon Islands. On 2011-04-15 at 22:15 LT while the ship was underway from Huatulco to Acapulco a Fire on the Auxiliary Engine Room was reported. 
Fire Alarm was given and Fire Emergency Teams deployed as per Emergency Plan. Compartment was isolated, ventilation shut off, fire dampers closed. Sprinkler Flexy Fog System was activated. 
WTD's were closed. A11 auxiliary engines were stopped due to the fire and critical services taken by the Emergency Generator. 
At 22:21 Fire Squad No.3 entered Auxiliary Engine Room, searched the area for casualties and tried to tackle the fire. No casualties were found in Auxiliary Engine Room. Fire Squads were a110cated for boundary cooling around the boundaries of the Auxiliary Engine Room and in the Funnel area. 
By the Master's order at 22:40 the fixed C02 fire extinguishing system was released into Auxiliary Engine Room. A11 fire squads remained in positions checking for hot spots and ready for boundary cooling. 
On 2011-04-16 at 01:53 L T Fire Squad # 3 re-entered the Auxiliary Engine Room in order to assess the condition of auxiliary engines. It was confirmed that that fire was extinguished. 
At 03 :30 WTD #2 leading to Auxiliary Engines Room was opened, compartment -was inspected by Chief Engineer and Fire Squad #3. Power has been restored with Auxiliary Engine # 1. 
On 2011-04-16 a11 passengers were evacuated with the help of the Mexican Navy by commercial pleasure boats from Huatulco. 
The Ship has been towed to Salinas Cruz were emergency repairs will be carried out

Fully cellular containership OOCL FINLAND was in collision with general cargo with container capacity TYUMEN-2 at the passing point near Hanerau-Hademarschen, in the Kiel Canal on 14 April at about 0750. The two vessels were approaching each other in dense fog when the OOCL FINLAND's bow strucked the wheelhouse of the TYUMEN-2 causing it to be torned off. There were 4 men on the wheelhouse deck at the time of the collision. The pilot and a channel controller were killed. Two other crewmembers were seriously injured. 
The OOCL FINLAND suffered minor damage to the bow and several containers were damaged. She continued on to Rendsburg while the TYUMEN-2 had to be towed to Fisherhuette to allow canal traffic to continue. The 400 dwt tanker CLIPPER SUND and another vessel ran into the canal embankment to avoid colliding wiht the wrecked vessels.
