SummaryOfEvents:
MV DHL Forester arrived at San Lorenzo, Argentina on 27 March 2001 to load 24,341mt of Soyabean meal in all her five cargo holds.  Loading operations were completed on the following day, followed by cargo fumigation, which was carried out by a shore fumigator.  Upon completion of the process, the vessel departed to her discharge ports of Geelong and Adelaide, Australia.  Effective ventilation and clearing of the fumigant necessitated that the re-circulation blower was run continuously for at least four days.  Instructions to start the ventilation of the cargo holds were received on 08 April 2011, however, it was not until 11 April that the cargo holds were ventilated because of adverse weather conditions.  All cargo holds covers were cracked open, manholes fully opened and arrangements made for natural ventilation.  However, five hours later, all had to be secured again due to forecasted adverse weather conditions.  It was decided, however, to only leave natural ventilation and a re-circulation blower.
On 12 April 2011, a loud explosion was heard at about 0330 (UTC) just forward of the bridge.  Preliminary inspection by the crew revealed that No. 5 hatch forward cover was open, whilst the aft end of the hatch cover was damaged.  Dense white smoke was observed coming out of the cargo hold.  All securing cleats, bolts, and hydraulic cylinder rams were damaged.  The crew applied boundary cooling, however, smoke immediately subsided, and no traces of fire were observed.  It was also observed that the power cable for the connection box on the re-circulation fan seemed burnt and the blower had fallen down to the first ladder platform.
No injuries or further structural damages were reported.

SOLASStatus: OCEAN OF LUCK: SOLAS, STELLAR LILAC: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
The incident between m/V Ocean of Luck and m/t Stellar LiIac on 13.04.2011 at 03 :40 L T while both ships were approaching to CJK PiIot Station, Chinese waters in position Lat.31 deg 07,8'N Long. 
122 Deg.36,8'E, m/t Stellar LiIac in process of overtaking m/v Ocean of Luck from her Starboard quarter hit her in area of Cargo hold N 5.

Location: 80 kms from Ciudad del Carmen, Mexico
SummaryOfEvents:
On 12 April 2011, at 0740 hrs, the workers accommodation (Flhotel) sea platform JUPITER managed by the company Cotemar that is hired by Pemex, collapsed in the Gulf of Mexico, 80 kilometres (43 nautical miles) off the coast from Ciudad del Carmen, Mexico, leaving no victims or any oil spill.  
The workers were evacuated from the semi-submersible dormitory platform after it began to lean to one side when water entered a pontoon.  There were no injuries as a result of the sudden inclination of the Jupiter and all 713 members of the crew were evacuated.  Since the platform is only used for housing and not for production, Pemex added the morning incident didn't cause any leakage of hydrocarbons.  "Pemex reiterated that neither production nor other activities in the area were affected".  
The evacuated workers were taken by transport ships to the Abkatun-Alfa platform.  Divers were sealing the affected pontoon on the Jupiter and Pemex said it expected the platform to be stabilized shortly and moved to an inspection area.
ShipType1: Mobile Offshore Unit, workers accommodation platform

SummaryOfEvents:
At 0454 UTC on 9 April 2011, the Gibraltar registered, container feeder vessel Philipp collided with the United Kingdom registered scallop dredger FV Lynn Marie 6nm south of the Isle of Man.  There were no injuries or pollution, but Lynn Marie was badly damaged and was towed to Port St Mary, Isle of Man.
After the collision, Philipp did not stop and neither her officer of the watch (OOW) nor her master tried to communicate with Lynn Marie to see if the fishing vessel required assistance. Philipp was about 20nm away from the location of the collision when her master eventually informed the coastguard of his vessel's involvement.
The MAIB investigation identified that Philipp's OOW had not properly assessed the risk of collision with Lynn Marie and that his actions to try and avoid the fishing vessel were contrary to the requirements of the collision regulations.
Lynn Marie's wheelhouse watchkeeper did not notice Philipp's alterations of course towards his vessel and did not realise that collision was imminent until it was too late to take effective avoiding action.
A recommendation has been made to Philipp's managers aimed at raising the competency of its bridge watchkeeping officers and ensuring that the navigation and anti-collision aids fitted on board its vessels are used effectively.

On 08.04.2011 A.M., the vessel was in process of berthing starboard side to at Dammam berth no. 22. After making fast one spring and two headlines on ship's bollards forward, while in process of making fast second spring, at around 1125 hrs., the pedestal roller fairlead on the starboard side gave way from its axle base welding and hit Mr. X, Trainee Seaman.

On 7 April 2011, a North Korean-flagged ship, HANG ROBONG, carrying 13,500 tones of rice collided with cargo ship SYED FARHADUDDIN and sank near the estuary of the port channel.  Two-thirds of the ship HANG ROBONG sunk.  All efforts to tug the ship after the collision failed.

At 14:00 hrs on 06/04/2011, the ship DOLE CHILE was docked in Puerto Castilla, Honduras and for compliance of ISPS requirement of USCG, they contract a diver for submarine inspection. The diver entered  the water at 14:20 hrs. At 15:30 hrs not receiving any communication from the diver, a search and rescue operation was carried out, which resulted in a body being found at 19:30 hrs of the same date. The search and rescue diver presented evidence of the incident, concluding that the diver has been crushed by the ship.

SOLASStatus: BANGA LANKA: Unknown/unspecified, HYANG RO BONG: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
The Democratic People's Republic of Korea flag ship HYANG RO BONG collided with ship BANGA LANKA outside Chittagong on 6 April 2011, hitting the front part of BANGA LANKA which was anchored at C-Anchorage.  HYANG RO BONG subsequently developed a list and began to sink.  The ship's 31 crew members were all safely transferred to another ship. 
The collision caused a crack in the engine room of HYANG RO BONG, and efforts to unload her cargo of 13,492 tonnes of rice failed due to damage to the ship's crane. A huge quantity of fuel oil was also found to be leaking into the bay from the ship. The Chittagoing Port Authority took steps to neutralise the oil to prevent pollution by spraying oil spill dispersant. 
It is possible that a salvage claim will be made against the owners/insurers of the cargo on board the vessel.

SOLASStatus: BINH MINH 28: Unknown/unspecified, PHUC HAI 5: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: The general cargo PHUC HAI 5 came in contact with cargo vessel BINH MINH 28 at the Cu Lao Cham Sea off the Central  province of Quang Nam on April 6 at 0310. The PHUC HAI 5 was enroute from Indonesia to Da Nang when its engine failed and was forced adrift. The BINH MINH 28, with 1,880 tons of clinkers, was moving from Thanh Hoa to An Giang. The two vessels struck each other head on because of bad weather and fog, in addition to limited visibility. The BINH MINH 28 sank. Responding vessels rescued six out of eleven of the BINH MINH 28 crew. Two crewmembers drowned but three remained missing.

The fishing vessel BTR TS 93357 sank Southwest of Vung Tau, Vietnam on April 6. 7 crewmen on board were forced into the water; one crewman was rescued by a passing squid boat and 6 men are still missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: waiting area of the Port of Tubarão
SummaryOfEvents: On 4 April 2011 the MV “FAITH N”, IMO 8618425, Panama Flag, type Ore Carrier, owned by the General Ore Carrier Corporation III Limited, was at anchor in the waiting area of the Port of Tubarão awaiting its release for berthing to make loading of iron ore.  On that same day the Captain-substitute would board the ship being transported from the Port of Vitoria by the boat "Anchieta". At 0925 the same day during the transfer to board the ship from the boat transporting him, the Captain-substitute lost balance and fell overboard, dying as a result of asphyxia by drowning, although it was immediately rescued and taken to shore. The investigation revealed the main contributory factor decisive to the fall and subsequent drowning was the use of an accommodation ladder aft of the ship to the access of the crew member on board in disagreement with the IMO guidelines on the subject, and the fact that the victim was not wearing lifejacket. The investigation also found that a comprehensive risks assessment had not been undertaken before the personnel transfer operation at sea.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: ALBERT RICKMERS [KOTA MANIS at the date of incident] sustained fire in its cargo hold no. 3. ALBERT RICKMERS was anchorage and waiting for pilot to board the vessel for berthing. The Mater notice fire rising from cargo holds no. 3 and 4. The Master ordered to release CO2 into all of the cargo holds. Then an explosion occurred in cargo hold no. 3 shaking the vessel violently.  After all efforts to extinguish the fire it was not until 11 days 6 hours and 5 minutes that fire was under control.
Vessel get fire at 23:30 at 03/04/2011 inside and docked to La Ceiba cabotaje port. All cargo lost. vessel partially lost, 1 fireman injured. Fire finished at 08:00 04/04/2011

At approximately 1200 (-6 UTC) on 1 April 2011 while FESCO OB was mooring at the Armco Steel Corporation in the Port of Houston, the electrician was seriously injured when a mooring line slipped off a roller and struck him on the head.  The electrician was provided first aid on the vessel and was subsequently transferred to shore by stretcher and was then transported by helicopter to hospital for treatment.  On 9 April 2011 he died as a result of his injuries.

The Panamanian-registered bulk carrier, MIRACH was stranded 3 miles southwest of Kadiyapattanam, India on 1 April 2011.  Damages were sustained to the hull and took water in holds nos. 1, 2,3 and 4.  All 25 crew members abandonned ship and were rescued.  No casualties or pollution were reported.
In April 2011, Venezuelan product tanker, ANN B foundered whilst moored at Maracaibo, Venezuela.

On the afternoon of 1st April 2011, the five metre open-top fishing ship "Lady Linda" went missing off Skerries Harbour, Co. Dublin with two crew on board, Mr A and Mr B. The upturned ship was found the following morning Saturday 2nd April off Clogher Head. Nether crewmen were with the ship. A large scale search effort commenced. The bodies of both casualties were recovered accidentally in a single trawl by the Irish FV D-51 "Guiding Light" on the early morning of Saturday 9th April 2011.

Mr A (26) and Mr B (41) were lifelong friend. Both men were experienced and qualified marine engineers in the fishing ship industry. Both men experienced in boat handling and had worked together on many occasions.

The trawler LADY ALEHA sank after being hit by 1,425 dwt Philippine-flagged tank M/V HAGONOY 2.8 miles off Sangley Point in the Cavite Province on April 1. Rescue divers were dispatched to the area and recovered two dead fishermen; one is still missing. It appeared that the tanker had no proper lookout at the bow and not enough lights in the dark.

On March 31, 2011 at approximately 0900, Liberian flagged bulk carrier, VOSTOK, sustained a fire on board while underway from Hualien, Taiwan, China to Caldera, Costa Rica in the North Pacific Ocean. While on duty checking the drain valve of the Waste Oil Settling Tank No. 1, the Fourth Engineer noticed that the drain valve was clogged. He attempted to use a stick to unblock the valve after dismounting the valve from the flange.  Sludge oil suddenly spouted out of the pipe and the oil ran through the oil pan, poop deck and grating and onto the main exhaust pipe to the composite boiler. Subsequently, a fire broke out at approximately 0858hrs.  After the Fourth Engineer failed to extinguish the fire with a portable extinguisher, the alarm was raised and the main engines stopped and the emergency fire pump was generated. The area was inspected and a strong blaze and smoke was still noted.  The Master ordered the CO2 system to be activated, which successfully extinguished the fire.  At approximately 1120, the crew members found that the fire had been put out, although the temperature in the engine room remained very high. Once the engine room had cooled sufficiency, they attempted to restart the main engine and found it difficult for the main engine to remain engaged. The ship requested tug assistance and was towed to Wakayama, Japan.  There were no reported injuries to the crew or incidents of pollution reported.

At 04.35 hrs on 31st March 2011, the vessel, which was anchored in Cashla Bay, began to drag anchor. At 04.55 hrs the vessel took the ground on the North Eastern part of the Bay.  No lives were lost, however, the vessel was extensively damaged.

On 31 March 2011 at 0309 Eastern Daylight Time, the downbound vessel BBC Steinhoeft, under the conduct of a pilot, ran aground in the South Shore Canal of the St. Lawrence Seaway downstream of St. Lambert Lock. Seaway traffic remained closed for 10 hours after the grounding until the vessel was refloated by 2 assisting tugs. There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this occurrence.

At 19:00 hrs, stevedores came on board and commenced unlashing cargo. At 19:16 hrs, security ramp watchman noticed that 40'RC/CH CRLU 9601045 I on chassis  SMLC 141398 collapsed. Out of two stevedores removing lashings in the front of the said  container, one managed to escape, the other one was pressed down by collapsing container. After the accident, police surrounded part of the Trailer Deck where accident took place with tape prohibiting entry for the crew.

InitialEvent: Breaking of a trailer on board Tamanou
SummaryOfEvents:
Depuis le 25 mars 2011, les remorqueurs TAMANOU et PORWI acheminent du minerai de nickel par barge au M/V VALENTE VENUS, un minéralier de 28000 tonnes mouillé en rade foraine. Ayant un faible tirant d’eau, le PORWI prend d’abord la barge à couple au wharf de Saint-Louis (commune de Mont-Dore, Nouvelle-Calédonie), jusqu’à la ligne de sonde des 5 mètres.
Puis, le TAMANOU le relaye au-delà de la ligne de sonde des 10 mètres jusqu’au minéralier, par un court voyage de 45 minutes. La barge est déchargée par les grues du VALENTE VENUS en deux heures environ.
Le 30 mars, les remorqueurs, la barge et leurs équipages sont en opérations depuis
5 jours, sans qu’il n’y ait eu d’interruption. Alors que le capitaine du TAMANOU « allonge » la remorque pour une nouvelle rotation, celle-ci casse brutalement à proximité du croc, fauchant le second capitaine et le second mécanicien, tous deux restés sur l’avant de la barge. Ils sont projetés à l’eau ; le second capitaine est mortellement blessé, le second mécanicien n’est que légèrement blessé.
Le chargement du minéralier, prévu initialement sur quatre jours avec deux barges de 1000 tonnes, prendra huit jours, du fait de la défection de la seconde barge.

Location: Crocodile rock, off Kolachel, Tamilnadu, India
SummaryOfEvents: The vessel was on laden passage from Visakhapatnam, India to Karachi, Pakistan, with a cargo of 25842 MT. iron ore, with a max. draft of 10.25 metres. On 29. 11.2011, the 3rd Officer relieved the Chief Officer for dinner at 1745 hrs and was the sole watch keeper on the bridge.The position was plotted hourly using GPS, the last position being at 1700 hrs.The vessel was on a course of 308 degrees True. At 1800 hrs., the 3rd Officer gave alt6eration command on auto pilot to 302 degrees but the vessel was not responding.Steering was switched to manual and helm put to hard a port. By this time, the vessel was already aground.

On 29 March 2011 at 16:00 hrs, the Chief officer took over the bridge watch while the vessel was approaching Cape Comorin, south coast of India, on a course of 308°T. Master and Second officer were also on the bridge. At 17:45 hrs Third officer took aver watch and relived Chief officer for dinner. Till this time the position of vessel was not platted and OOW was unaware of the current navigational situation. At 18:00 hrs, OOW saw the crocodile rock on the bow when it was at a very close distance. He gave hard a port on the helm but it was too late and the stem of the vessel hit the "crocodile rock" at 18:03 hrs in position 08°04.9'NI077°17.2'E, 3.5 nm off Muttam point, Indian Coast. On 4 April all 25 crew members abandoned the vessel.
There were no loss of lives or any injury reported.

InitialEvent: Accident during evacuation of sick passenger
SummaryOfEvents: Passenger died after being dropped into the sea during transfer to lifeboat for hospital treatment ashore

On the 28th of March 2011 an ordinary seaman was fatally injured on board MV EMSSKY, while leaving Ballah Station under pilotage north bound in the Suez Canal. 
The deceased was part of the forward mooring team, taking care of the mooring line retrieval under the supervision of the vessels second officer.
At the time of the accident the MV EMSSKY was, with a tug fastened to the stern swinging off its berth position with the last forward mooring line still fast ashore.
On being ordered by the vessels master to let go all forward the line could not be taken off the bollard as it was jammed by other turns on the bollard.
The second officer who was operating the winches ordered the loose end of the mooring line to be put on the port winch capstan and tried, after telling both crew to stay clear, to pull the line free. This allegedly caused the rope to break and struck the later deceased on the head.
Immediately the unconscious and bleeding seaman was tended to and a shore side ambulance alerted. The vessels Chief Officer and assisting other crew attempted to reanimate the lifeless body, without success.
After returning to its initial berthing position local authorities boarded the vessel and a doctor officially declared the seaman’s death.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: CONDOR VITESSE: Unknown/unspecified, LES MARQUISES: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Between St Malo and St Hellier
SummaryOfEvents: The catamaran ferry CONDOR VITESSE was in a collision with French trawler LES MARQUISES in thick fog between St Malo and St Helier on March 28. LES MARQUISES sank while CONDOR VITESSE suffered only slight damage to its starboard bow. Two of the trawler's fishermen were rescued by the ferry and a third was transfered to a hospital by lifeboat where he died later from hypothermia.

THE SHIP HAD COMPLETED DISCHARGE OF CARGO AND CREW WAS CLOSING THE TWEEDECK HATCH IN HOLD NO. 2.  THE HATCHES OF THIS SHIP ARE CLOSED USING SHIP΄S CRANES AND WIRE-ROPES. ONE OF THE PONTOONS OF THE HATCH FELL AND COUSED THE DEATH OF A SEAMN AND THE SEVERING OF THE LOWER PARTS OF THE LAEGS OF ANOTHER.

Location: 9 miles east of Eddystone Rocks, UNITED KINGDOM
SummaryOfEvents:
Our Boy Andrew, a UK registered fishing ship, departed Looe on the early rising tide of 24 March 2011. At 07:10, the skipper, who was the only person on board, shot the port net and then towed it until 11:40 hrs, at which time he decided to haul the gear. It is believed that he was manually guiding the net onto the rotating net drum when he was pulled onto the drum and sustained fatal injuries. The ship was later found about 28 miles from her last sighted position after an extensive search and rescue operation.

The investigation concluded that a drawstring toggle on the left-hand side of the storm hood on the skipper’s jacket had become entangled in the net as it was being hauled on board. Evidence indicated that the skipper had then reached towards the operating control lever to stop the net drum. He was unable to do so, and died as a result of injuries to his upper body.

ON 23 MARCH 2011 WHILE THE VESSEL "KAI BAO" WAS ON HER LOADES PASSAGE FROM CAMPHA, VIETNAM TO DONG GUAN, CHINA. THIRD OFFICER. WAS FOUND MISSING AT 0520LT. AT THIS TIME THE VESSEL WAS IN POSITION 25º53.1N/ 113º50.0E. SEARCH WAS MADE ON BOARD FOR THE VICTIM, BUT ENDED IN FUTILITY. THE VESSEL CONTINUED ON HER PASSAGE AND REACHED NEXT PORT OF CALL, AT 1300HRS., ON THE SAME DAY.
AS THE  CREW WAS NOT FOUND ON BOARD DURING SEARCH, IT WAS ASSUMED THAT HE FELL OVERBOARD AND THE MATTER WAS REPORTED TO SEARCH & RESCUE CENTER, POLICE, QUARANTINE , IMIGRATION & THE AGENT.

SOLASStatus: FUKUJU MARU: SOLAS, KAISHO MARU: Unknown/unspecified
Location: About 10 kms east off Iwata, Shizuoka
SummaryOfEvents: F/V FUKUJU MARU and KAISHO MARU collided in waters about 10 kms east off Iwata, Shizuoka Prefecture on March 22. Two men were killed, one went missing, and four other crewmembers sustained non-life threatening injuries.

InitialEvent: Slip while preparing to descent stairway
SummaryOfEvents:
The bosun of a platform support vessel was returning to the deck having had his afternoon tea break.  As he went down a stairway to the changing room to don his PPE he slipped at the top of the stairs as he was turning round to face the stairs to descend them.  He bumped down the stairs and bruised his spine, suffered intermittent chest pains and bumped the back of his head.  There were no witnesses the injuries.

The bosun was wearing jeans, a tee shirt and sandals with heel straps.  He managed to get back to his cabin before he raised the alarm.  The medical assistant attended to him but it was decided to evacuate him by helicopter to hospital after consulting with a hospital doctor.  

Examination of the stairs found them to be in good condition, unobstructed, dry and well lit.  The vessel was not rolling or pitching and the company’s internal investigation concluded that the bosun misjudged his foot placement as he was turning.  Interviews with the crew indicated that as the stairs were fairly steep the bosun always descended them facing the treads in accordance with best practice.

At 07:58 hours L T on 21 March 2011, A/B informed me in the bridge that the carpenter was missing. I instructed the Chief mate and the Bosun to look for him and that maybe he was just in the toilet or other parts of the accommodation. After almost 30 minutes they reported that they could not find him. Then I decided to rung the emergency alarm at 08:35 hours to muster all the crew but still there was no sign of the carpenter. The crew were then divided into groups to thoroughly check the entire accommodations, engine room, forecastle, and cargo spaces. 
At 09;12 hours they reported that he could still not be located. I decided to call the company OPA Capt at 09:15 hours to inform him of the situation on board. After reporting to him, I called the Port authorities the East Service and Marine Safety by VHF channel 12 and 7 respectively and the ship's agent was also informed. 
09:37 hrs- Coast Guard carne on board for investigation. 09:50 hrs- MPA authority on board. 
10:15 hrs - Coast Guard off. 
10:25 hrs- MPA off.

The cargo vessel Min Ningde Cargo 0202 capsized and sank off the Ningde City, Fujian Province on March 20. Six people on the cargo ship fell into water: two were rescued, and a search was done for the missing others.

Welders were conducting hot work replacing the longitudinal centerline bulkhead between preload tanks 2P and 2S. While those workers were washing the old plate off the Grame 8 bulkhaed, the adjacent refrigeration store room caught on fire. The crew members were able to extinguish the fire. There were no injuries or incidents of pollution reported.

On March 19, the passenger cargo ship was struck by a tall wave and violently listed. During the incident, one crewmember had been injured as he had been thrown from his bunk and strucked his head. He went to hospital with serious headaches, and died ten days later. At the time of the incident, a stabilizer retracted when it should not have, causing the vessel to pitch and roll. The passenger ro/ro serviced between Newfoundland and Nova Scotia.

Location: about 3 miles east of Caye Caulker village, Belizean waters
SummaryOfEvents: The general cargo vessel HELGA loaded with salt, sank in rough weather about 3 miles east of Caye Caulker Village on 19 March. 8 crewmembers were rescued and 3 (the Captain, chief engineer and the helmsmann) were missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On the 16th of March 2011, MV “ANNEGRET” departed from the port of Emden, heading towards the North Sea under pilot assistance. The bridge was manned by the captain, the 2nd mate and the pilot while the vessels crew was executing last preparations for sea. 
At the position of pilot disembarkation the pilot was released at slow speed and the deck cadet was ordered by the 2nd mate to secure the pilot embarkation ladder and report to the bridge when completed.
The 2nd mate showed the pilot down and returned to the bridge where he assisted the captain with the navigation, continuing the intended voyage as planned. After about 20 minutes had passed since the pilot left the vessel, the cadet had not yet reported back to the 2nd mate.
After trying different means of locating the cadet, the 2nd mate reported to the captain that he was not able to get hold of the cadet. The captain immediately took action as required by ships procedures, initiating a full ships search, informing the local traffic service and with their knowledge and approval started the Man over Board manoeuvre. 
Local Search and Rescue services soon took over the search coordination and assisted with one vessel and a helicopter. 
All efforts to find the missing seaman were without positive result and the operation was suspended after sunset. The ANNEGRET returned to Emden were further investigations were undertaken by local authorities.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The vessel was on passage from Santos, Brazil to a port in China with a cargo of soya beans in bulk.  The voyage was uneventful until 16 March a sudden change in the engine noise and vessel vibration indicated that the vessel was aground.  A sudden list to port side had also developed.  The vessel had stopped and the officers on the bridge could see a cliff in close proximity of the ship.

When making fast to a buoy, an AB stood in an open bight of a mooring wire.  As the weight came on the line, it suddenly went taught across his chest causing a crush injury and eventually flipping him over the top rail of the ship's side.

He was recovered from the water and airlifted to hospital but never regained consciousness.

ON 9/3/2011 THE PUMPMAN OF THE SHIP WENT USING HARNESS AND LIFE LINE, TO THE FORECASTLE WITH THE CHIEF OFFICER AND ONE SEAMAN TO INSPECT AND TAKE MEASURES AGAINST DAMAGE CAUSED BY HEAVY WEATHER.  DURING HIS RETURN BACK TO ACCOMMODATION HE WAS STRUCK BY WAVE WHICHTHREW HIM TO THE SIDE OF THE CENTER WALKWAY AND WAS HURT IN STOMACH.  ON 12 MARCH HIS STOMACH WAS INFLATED AND ON 13 HE FELL FROM A CHAIR HE WAS SITTING AND DIED.

Location: Indian Ocean, off the Comorros Islands
SummaryOfEvents: On 13 March 20111, stern trawler, IRIA FLAVIA took water and foundered in the Indian Ocean off the Comorros Islands after pumping operations failed.  All 11 crew members were safely rescued.
The Japanese passenger ship CAMELLIA KISS capsized and foundered after being struck by a tsunami whilst moored at Oshima Island, Kesennuma, Miyagi, Japan on 11 March 2011.

The Panamanian-flagged general cargo ship ASIA SYMPHONY was stranded at dock, having sustained severe hull damage, after being struck by a tsunami, whilst moored at Kamaishi, Iwate, Japan on 11 March 2011.  The ship subsequently refloating in October 2011 and towed to Hiroshima, Japan for breaking up.

The fishing vessel EL CHOLO is reported missing after setting sail from Puerto Rico de Bayovar, Peru. The fishing vessel with 10 men may have not known of the tusnami warning. Its 10 fishermen have been missing since the earthquake and tsunami in Japan on March 11.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The Japanese passenger/ro-ro ship FERRY OSHIMA caught fire after being struck by a tsunami whilst moored at Kesennuma, Miyagi, Northeast of Japan on 11 March 2011.  The ship was completely burnt out.

The Russian Federation-registerd fishing carrier KHRIZOLITOVYY sustained engine damage and was stranded after being stuck by a tsunami whilst moored at Ofunato, Iwate, Japan on 11 March 2011.

All 13 crew members were rescued by local fishing vessels.  No injuries or pollution were reported.

The Japanese-registered passenger ship KAIO caught fire at Kesennuma, Miyagi, Japan on 11 March 2011.  The ship was completely burnt out. A blaze ignited after the port was struck by a tsunami.  The ship was declared not financially viable for repair and subsequently towed to Muroran, Japan for breaking up.

On 3 March 2013, the general cargo ship GLOVIS MERCURY, from the Republic of Korea was stranded on shore after being stuck by a tsunami whilst moored at Sendai, Miyagi, Japan.  The ship was damaged beyond economical repair and subsequently broken up.

The Japanese-registered fishing vessel KIKU MARU NO. 35, was washed out of harbour and stranded inland by a tsunami at Hachinohe, Japan on 11 March 2011.  The fishing vessel was damaged beyond economical repair and broken up.

WHILE SHIP WAS DISCHARGING CARGO IN PORT OF INDIA, CHIEF OFFICER WENT OUT TO THE WHARF IN ORDER TO CHECK SHIP΄S DRAFTS.  HE WAS AMID SHIPS WHEN A BULLDOZEN USED TO UNLOAD THE SHIP HIT AND RUM OVER HIM.  THE BULLDOZEN WAS MOVING BACK.  HE WAS TAKEN TO HOSPITAL BUT ONE HOUR LATER IT WAS ANNOUNCED THAT HE DIED.

The F/V HARVEST TIME, with two crewmembers aboard, capsized in the vicinity of Neuse River in Pamlico Sound, North Carolina on March 8. The crew aboard F/V ISLAND GIRL located the HARVEST TIME and rescued one crewmember. The other fisherman is still missing.

SOLASStatus: MSC PAMELA: SOLAS, THERESA LIBRA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: Fully cellular containership MSC Pamela (107849 gt, built 2005) and Combined chemical and oil tank Theresa Libra (11254 gt, built 2007) were in collision in position lat 17 04 N, long 116 51 E

ShipsInvolved: COSCO HONG KONG (IMO 9227778), ZHE LING YU YUN 135 (-)
SOLASStatus: COSCO HONG KONG: SOLAS, ZHE LING YU YUN 135: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At 02.18 hrs on  6 March 2011, the UK registered container ship Cosco Hong Kong collided with the China registered fish transportation ship Zhe Ling Yu Yun 135. The accident occurred in international waters off the coast of Zhejiang Province, China. Zhe Ling Yu Yun 135 sank almost immediately, with the loss of 11 lives. Cosco Hong Kong was not damaged. 

On impact, Cosco Hong Kong’s officer of the watch felt an unusual vibration and immediately put the engine telegraph to stop. He did not see Zhe Ling Yu Yun 135 immediately before or after the collision and he was unaware of what the container ship had struck. Cosco Hong Kong remained drifting in the vicinity for over 1 hour while the master tried to establish what had happened. In the absence of any evidence that a collision had occurred, Cosco Hong Kong then resumed passage to Yangshan, China.

The Taizhou Maritime Rescued Co-ordination Centre was notified that Zhe Ling Yu Yun 135 was missing at 20:21 hrs, 18 hrs after the collision. An air and sea search failed to find any trace of the ship or her crew. The Wreck of the Zhe Ling Yu Yun 135 was eventually located on 17 March 2011 close to the position of the collision.

On the night of 05 to March 6, 2011, the passenger vessel (supply vessel) "FAST TITAN", IMO 9579937, callsign WDF4842, flag United States of America, GT 449, DWT 226, built 2009, was sailing toward 345° from Santos Basin towards the port of Rio de Janeiro with the use of autopilot, with a speed of approximately 20 knots. The Brazilian flagged fishing boat "Evilázio",  wooden hull,  had left Jurujuba - Niterói and was sailing towards the fishing area when the collision occurred. At the time of the accident only one crewmember of the fishing boat found himself awake in the manoeuver, and the others were sleeping. The fishing boat was badly damaged and there was flooding and partial sinking. The vessel "FAST TITAN" manoeuvered over to rescue the crew of the fishing boat. One crewmember of the fishing boat died during the rescue and another one was injured.

InitialEvent: Incident due to heavy weather conditions
SummaryOfEvents: Sardine fishing boat KIN is believed to have sunk off Guaymas, Sonora State, after failing to arrive in port on March 6. Searchers with Mexico's navy found the bodies of four crewmen: 5 others were still missing. There were high winds and strong waves. The last contact with the boat was on March 5.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The Turkish-registered cargo ship KOCA REIS caught fire in boiler flue in the Mediterranean Sea, 10 miles north of Annaba, Morocco at 1200 hrs (local time) on 3 March 2011.  The fire was brought under control with assistance from the Algerian Coastguard ships.  No injuries were reported.  The engine room was completely burnt out.  She was towed to Ravenna, Italy by AHTS EMRE OMUR in April for cargo discharge.  KOCA REIS was damaged beyond economical repair and arrived at Aliaga, Turkey on 21 September 2011 for breaking up.

Le 1er Mars 2011, le navire de pêche fileyeur LE VAGABOND se trouve à environ
21.milles dans le Nord-Est de l’île de Batz ; il effectue sa dernière marée avant la vive eau. En début d’après midi, après avoir récupéré l’ensemble de son matériel de pêche, le patron met le cap vers Roscoff, sous pilote automatique, à une vitesse de 6 noeuds.
Un vent de force 4 Beaufort souffle du secteur Nord-Est et la mer est agitée. Environ
trente minutes plus tard, le navire prend de la gîte sur bâbord, s’enfonce par l’arrière et coule rapidement à 18 milles dans le Nord/Nord-Est de l’île de Batz par 70 mètres de fond.
L’équipage, qui n’a pas réussi à gonfler le radeau de survie, est contraint de se jeter à l’eau ; il est récupéré au bout de 25 minutes, en état d’hypothermie, par le caseyeur STEREN.MOR. Le CROSS Corsen, alerté à ce moment par le patron du STEREN MOR, coordonne l’opération jusqu’au débarquement des trois naufragés au port de Roscoff deux heures plus tard. Les trois hommes sont conduits à l’hôpital par les sapeurs pompier de Morlaix.
LE VAGABOND était équipé d’une balise RLS SARSAT /COSPAS 406 MHz. Deux
messages de détresse émis par cet équipement ont été reçus le 02 Mars 2011 en début d’après-midi.

BOTH AUX.ENGINES WERE STOPPED. EMERGENCY DIESEL GENERATOR WAS STARTED, ENGINE ROOM EVACUATED AND CO2 INJECTED. FIRE WAS EXTINGUISHED AND VESSEL WAS TOWED TO DRYDOCK AFTER DISCHARGE OF CARGO. CASUALTY DID NOT RESULT IN ANY INJURY OR POLLUTION.

SummaryOfEvents:
On 28 February 2011, the Panamanian fishing vessel LAUTARO caught fire after an explosion in the engine room, whilst undergoing repairs at Manta, Ecuador at 0945 hrs (local time).  The blaze was brought under control after five hours with assitance from fire fighting tug and local fire services.  All crew members were evacuated; one crew member and 7 assisting persons were reported injured.  

The bridge and accommodation area of the vessel were completely burnt out and the vessels' helicopter was destroyed.

On 27 February 2011, the seiner Erika was fishing for capelin on the fishing grounds west of Iceland. At 21:00 hrs, while securing the third throw of the seine for the day, one fisherman fell overboard. The remaining crew were able to recover the fisherman, but he was unconscious, and it was not possible to resuscitate him. A doctor was hoisted on board from a rescue helicopter, and the doctor declared the fisherman dead.

SummaryOfEvents: At about 1258LT on Feb 27th 2011,China flagged vessel M/V Xin Zhang Zhou on her way from Bayuquan Port to Jiangyin Port, China collided with a Chinese fishing boat Liao Wa Yu 75060 during its anchorage due to the machine failure in the position of 38°28′.0N/121°03′.6E. It caused the fishing boat sunk, all crew members were rescued.

Location: Bakau Bay off Pulau Berhalas, Bintan, Indonesia
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: On 27 January 2011 at 1130, the asphalt/bitumen tanker, AB9 sank after striking a reef in Bakau Bay, off Pulau Berhalas, Bintan, Indonesia.  The tanker sustained damage to hull, took in water and subsequently sank at 1300 hours later the same day.  All 14 crew abandoned ship to liferapts and were rescued by local fishing vessels and the Indonesian navy.  No injuries or pollution were reported.  The wreck was raissed using a floating crane by Mammoet Salvage and T&T Bisso on 18 October 2011 and towed to Kijang, Indonesia.

On 24 February 2010, at about 2115, while the vessel was on anchor on the exterior zone of the Bay of Viviero en route to Split, the master decided to lower the vessel's fast rescue boat after he observed a floating object close to the ship.  It was claimed that three crew members boarded the rescue boat and left the vessel.  Soon after, the outboard engine developed a fault and the rescue boat eventually drifted close to the beach.  It was reported that at one point in time, the rescue boat capsized and all three crew members were thrown overboard.  Given that they were close to the shore, two of the crew members ran on the beach asking for help.  However, the third crew member could not be retreived.  His body was eventually found the following morning by the Spanish SAR services.

At 15:24 hrs on 26 February 2011, the platform supply ship SBS Typhoon was undertaking functional trials of a newly installed dynamic positioning (DP) system while alongside in Aberdeen Harbour. Full ahead pitch was inadvertently applied to the port and starboard controllable pitch propellers (CPP), causing the ship to move along the quay. Contact was made with the standby safety vessel Vos Scout and the PSV Ocean Searcher, causing structural and deck equipment damage
A training vessel NTS-313 suffered a fire while berthed in Nikolayev, Ukraine on February 26. City fire teams quickly extinguished the fire, but one man died in the sauna, where the fire started.

The Chinese general cargo M/V YONGXIN loaded with 4100 mt of silica sand collided with a Chinese fishing boat in East China Sea, off Zhejiang Province on February 25. The fishing boat sank and two crewmembers are missing.

SummaryOfEvents:
El pesquero “Faro de Hércules” se encontraba en zona de pesca en el Océano Pacífico SE, expuesto a vientos de  30 nudos con rachas de hasta 40 nudos y olas de 4 metros. En circunstancias que había terminado de recoger un aparejo de anzuelos de 10 millas de extensión y cuando se dirigía a 8 nudos a recuperar otro aparejo calado, sufrió una escora progresiva a la banda de estribor hasta volcarse completamente. La escora permanente fue producto del ingreso de agua de mar a la factoría del pesquero, a través de una pequeña puerta, utilizada para el ingreso de la pesca a la factoría, presumiblemente debido a los golpes de mar que recibía la nave en dicho sector, cuando dicho compartimiento estaba vacío, lo que no les permitió conocer oportunamente la deficiencia de estanqueidad.
El rápido ingreso de agua al sector, la falla de la bomba de achique eléctrica instalada al interior de la factoría, producto de la propia inundación; sumado a las adversas condiciones de mar y viento, y a la condición de que con 20 ° de escora los trancaniles de la factoría quedaban bajo el agua, fueron factores que contribuyeron a que el volcamiento y posterior  hundimiento del pesquero ocurriera en un corto lapso de tiempo.
El abandono de la nave comenzó por iniciativa propia la dotación, utilizando las balsas salvavidas, procedimiento el cual no se apegó a lo dispuesto, debido principalmente a que el equipo de gestión no dispuso el oportuno abandono de la nave, al desestimar el riesgo de volcamiento.  No obstante lo anterior y a pesar del mal tiempo, 38 tripulantes salvaron la vida, encontrándose 4 de ellos desaparecidos.
La activación de la señal de Distress desde el equipo de radio, y la falta de transmisión del equipo de posicionamiento satelital de la nave, fueron elementos claves para que el MRCC Chile coordinara efectivamente los medios de rescate.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The Philippine passenger vessel DOMINIC, bound to San Jose, Occidental Mindoro, sank off the coast of Magsaysay on February 24. The number of passengers onboard was unknown.

SummaryOfEvents: The Indonesian passenger ferry BALIBO with 33 passengers on board and six-wheel and two-wheel vehicles, encountered tropical cyclone Carlos and sank in Pukuafu Strait, East Nusa Tenggara on February 23. The vessel was ultimately pushed onto rocks off the shore. The ship was hit by sea waves of more than three meters in height. All passengers were rescued.

SummaryOfEvents: The Indian barge NOOR IV cracked and sank in blustery seas on February 20. Six men were rescued and one crewmember was missing. An inquiry conducted by the Captain of Ports into the sinking of the barge revealed that apart from the weight of the cargo, the strong waves aggravated the crack on the damaged vessel, causing it to break into two.

SummaryOfEvents: The Panamanian-flagged bulk carrier sustained broken tail shaft in the Pacific Ocean, 90 miles north of Manus Island, Papua New Guinea on 19 February 2011.  The ship was damaged beyond economical repair and broken up at Jingjiang, People's Republic of China in July 2011.

On 18 February 2011, whilst fishing for mussels close to the shore in Waterford Estuary approximately 0.5 nautical miles (NW) North of Duncannon, the MFV “Na Buachailli” capsized and sank.  The skipper survived the incident, but his crewman was lost.  His body was later recovered from the water on 21 March 2011.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On the 17th of February 2011, outbound from Fredereikstad Norway, the container vessel “GODAFOSS” ran aground after the pilot disembarkation. 
At the moment of grounding the master was the sole person on bridge, taking care of navigation, communication and steering of the vessel.
The situation evolved through an obvious disorientation of the master, resulting in misjudgement of the vessels position leading to the grounding.

Location: On passage from Newport News, USA to Hamburg, Germany
SummaryOfEvents:
On the morning of 17 February 2011, while on passage from Newport News, USA to Hamburg, Germany, the Master authorised the chief officer to assemble a team to clear mooring lines from the aft deck. Due to the recent heavy weather and the presence of green water on the deck, two mooring lines had shifted from their stowed positions against the aft bulkhead of the engine casing and were in danger of being washed overboard where it was feared they might foul the propeller.

The chief officer assembled a team of eight to assist with clearing the lines. While the team was engaged in working, the deck became engulfed with green water from two successive large waves which struck working crew members causing some to lose their footing, one of whom was washed overboard and subsequently was not recovered.

At 0546 (UTC+1) on 15 February 2011, the feeder container vessel K-Wave ran aground 13 miles east of Malaga on the south Spanish coast, while on passage from Algeciras to Valencia. At the time of the grounding she was proceeding at full speed, and the bridge was unmanned. 
The Spanish coastguard attempted to contact the ship on very high frequency (VHF) radio shortly after the grounding but received no response until 06:30, when the master initially denied that the incident had occurred. The coastguard mobilised rescue services to attend the ship  that included a helicopter, lifeboat and salvage tug. 
Spanish authorities boarded later that day, inspected the ship and found no signs of damage. On 16 February, the owners’ salvage plan was approved by the authorities and K-Wave was refloated the same day with the assistance of a powerful salvage tug. She was then escorted to Malaga, where a classification society survey confirmed that her hull had not been damaged by the incident. K-Wave was given approval to resume service the following day.

SummaryOfEvents:
A 22 metre fishing vessel was engaged in trawling. In the wheelhouse were her skipper and mate. The swell was between 4 to 5 metres and there were isolated rain showers which reduced visibility to between 1 and 2 nautical miles. The fishing vessel was showing her navigational lights and lights to indicate that she was trawling.
The skipper became aware of a merchant ship on the fishing vessel’s starboard side. He was able to see the vessel both on radar and on his AIS and could visually see the vessels masthead lights and red side light. He identified the vessel as a container ship and saw that she was proceeding at 18 knots. Although the closet point of approach was small, the container ship would pass astern of the fishing vessel.
The skipper adjusted his own course slightly to port to increase the closest point of approach between the vessels. Shortly after this, the skipper saw the green side light of the container ship and assumed that the merchant ship had adjusted his course to port.
On the bridge of the container ship, the master was acting as officer of the watch. He had not rested for over 36 hours and was slightly irritable. While the master was explaining the correct administrative methods to a junior officer, the lookout report a light fine on the container ship’s port bow. The master identified the light as a fishing vessel and concluded that the container vessel was overtaking He adjusted his vessels course by 10 degrees to starboard and then became engaged in adjusting the radars settings in an effort to locate the target on the display. 

Two minutes later, the lookout reported the light again, this time very close on the starboard side. The master immediately took avoiding action by completing a wheel over to starboard but was unable to prevent the container ship colliding with the fishing vessel. Two of the fishing vessel's crew were thrown overboard but both were later recovered, one by the rescue boat from the container ship who had remained on station following the collision. The fishing vessel was badly damaged and was towed by to port by the local lifeboat.

Location: Tanaak Cape, Afognak Island, AK, United States of America
SummaryOfEvents: On 11 February 2011, at 0013 hrs (local time), the fishing vessel MIDNITE SUN, registered by the United States of America, carrying a crew of 5 persons was stranded in heavy weather at Tanaak Cape, Afognak Island, AK, the United States of Amercia.  All 5 crew members were rescuted by USCG MH-60J helicopter and taken to Kodiak, AK.  No injuries were reported.  The vessel sustained severe demage to hull and bunker tanks.  Approximately, 4,500 gallons of bunker fuel spilled into the sea.  Salvage operations were postponed until April due to the adverse weather conditions.

The ALEXANDRA's stern sank at about 92 metres at the sea east of Okinoshima and its bow remained afloat. The aft section of the vesse sunk in about 130 - 160 metres at the sea off Ulsan, which is about 16 miles east of the nearest shoreline. Four Russian sailors died and seven others went missing.

On 8 February 2011, the general cargo ship Musketier coming from Spain and bound to Germany, was in the northeast bound lane to the Dover TSS.

When she was abeam buoy zc 1, she did not alter course as planned and went on steering a steady course towards the coast. At 12:41 am local time, she stranded on the coast of Ambleteuse commune. A seaside resident witnessed the event and sounded the alarm to Gris-Nez MRCC.

Taking the opportunity of the high tide, she got refloated by herself. The ship had been directed to anchor on roads in the Dick area where she had undergone a safety inspection by an assessment team. As no damage had been observed, she resumed her voyage towards Brake (Germany).

The sailors were in a lifeboat when it plummeted about 30 meters into the sea from the top of the deck. The ship crewmembers were taken to Bristol Royal infirmary where one died.

Mallaig all weather lifeboat and Stornoway coastguard helicopter deployed, and the crew were airlifted off the ship. Location: Antarctic Peninsula, just north of Detaille Island
SummaryOfEvents: On 31st January 2011 the MV POLAR STAR struck an un-surveyed rock whilst anchoring just north of Detaille Island at the Antarctic Peninsula. The vessel is currently floating free, unassisted, in 37 metres of water. There are 80 passengers and 35 crew members on board, and no reports of injuries. The Captain reported that there is no apparent oil spill outside the ship, but booms have been deployed as a precaution. An initial assessment of the damage indicates a breech to the outer hull of the vessel, with the inner hull intact. The relevant Maritime Rescue Co-Ordination Centre has been alerted and is assessing the situation.
The F/V DANER capsized off Canomay village in Claveria town in Masbate on January 31. The vessel was recovered the next day, but at least four fishermen were missing.

General cargo ship BOHAI CHALLENGE ran aground on wave dissipating blocks in Kanazawa Port at 0040 (JST), Jan. 30, 2011. The weather at the scene was snow and visibility was poor around the time the grounding occurred. All the crewmembers were safely rescued, however the fuel oil of the ship leaked into the sea.

Location: In the Cattewater, off Plymouth Yacht Haven
SummaryOfEvents: The ex-Navy minesweeper YARMOUTH NAVIGATOR sank in the Cattewater off Plymouth Yacht Haven at Mount Batten on January 30. All four people on board went overboard; three of the casualties were pulled from the water by staff from the Plymouth Yacht Haven Marina, but the fourth was missing.

Location: Off the port of Merak on Java Island, Indonesia
SummaryOfEvents: A fire broke out at around 03.00 local time (2000 GMT Thursday, 27th January), soon after the ferry LAUT TEDUH 2 left Merak port on Java Island, Indonesia, en route to Sumatra. Around 420 people were rescued, but 13 died, mostly as a result of of drowning after jumping into the sea to avoid the fire. Around 200 people were seriously injured. It appears that the fire broke out on the car deck, and could have been caused by a lit cigaretter butt.

Nine of the ten missing fishermen, who stayed about 12 days in the sea were rescued by local fishermen between Zamboanga del Norte and Negros Province on February 8. SOLASStatus: Bina 98 (Deck Cargo Barge): Unknown/unspecified, BINA MARINE 59: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
DEATH OF ONE AB FROM SRS TUG BINA MARINE 59 (IMO NO. 9571844) INSIDE THE VOID SPACE OF SRS FLAT TOP BARGE BINA 98 (OFFICIAL NO. 392121), ALONGSIDE JETTY KM 57, TG UBAN, INDONESIA, 26 JANUARY 2011 AT ABOUT 1500HRS
	In the morning of 25 January 2011, the owners instructed the crew of Bina Marine 59 to open some manhole covers (void spaces) onboard Bina 98 (LoA 67m) for survey purposes. Both Bina Marine 59 and the unmanned Bina 98 are owned by the same owner.
The next day at about 1100hrs, three surveyors boarded Bina 98 to survey the open void spaces. Subsequently, the surveyors requested the crew of Bina Marine 59 to open more void spaces; namely no. 1(S) and no. 6(P). The respective manhole covers were removed at about 1400hrs.
Apparently, two surveyors were on the main deck taking photographs of the no. 6(P) void space when one of them fell into the space. The remaining surveyor (not wearing breathing apparatus) immediately went into the space to assist his colleague but came up almost immediately when he felt dizzy. He cried for help.
Indonesian AB Aprianus Paladang was the first crew to arrive and saw the surveyor lying on the bottom of the no. 6(P) void space. Without wearing any breathing apparatus, he went into the space but was soon lying unconscious on the bottom.
At about 1500hrs, the 2 men (surveyor and AB Aprianus Paladang) were rescued by crew (wearing breathing apparatus) from Bina Marine 51 and Bina Marine 65 - these vessels were lying in the vicinity. However, only the surveyor recovered and the unconscious AB was rushed to the local hospital but was pronounced dead.
Investigations revealed that it was an unintended entry (no. 6(P) void space) and thus no precautions were taken e.g. rescue and resuscitation equipment available for immediate use by the entrance to the space, designated attendant etc. There is no evidence to suggest that the deceased, a suitably trained crew, was unaware of the precautions when entering enclosed spaces. In all probability, his entry into the no. 6(P) void space, on his own accord, was simply an act to save life. But it was also a fatal act and could be attributed to the human error of incorrect recognition .
Following this incident, the owners revised their ‘Entry into Enclosed Spaces’ check-list (written in English and Bahasa) vis-à-vis IMO Resolution A.1050(27) ‘Revised Recommendations for entering enclosed spaces aboard ships’. This Resolution includes a section on safety management:
3.3.2	Crew members should be trained, as appropriate, in enclosed space safety, including familiarization with onboard procedures for recognizing, evaluating and controlling hazards associated with entry into enclosed spaces.

En condición nocturna navegaban de vuelta encontrada por el Canal Moraleda el Wellboat "Cacique I", con rumbo general Norte y con rumbo Sur el Wellboat "Oddegutt", con buenas condiciones de visibilidad, viento calma y mar llana.
Ambas naves se detectaron con suficiente antelación. El oficial de guardia del "Oddegutt", cuando estaban a una distancia de aproximadamente 4 millas, llamó por VHF  con la idea de pasar verde con verde, a lo que el oficial de guardia del "Cacique" se opuso, indicando que pasaran rojo con rojo, (dado la condición de canal que tenía el área de navegación). Continuaron ambas naves acercándose de manera tal que el y Oddegutt", mostraba su luz verde, sin embargo dada la peligrosa cercanía (40 metros aproximadamente) el "Oddegutt" decide abortar su cruce de verde con verde y avisa por VHF que pasará rojo con rojo y cae a estribor mostrando su rojo. Por su parte el "Cacique" al ver cruzar la otra nave y su cercanía da atrás la máquina, con lo que el "Cacique" por efecto de la fuerza lateral de la hélice bota su proa a babor, cruzándose ante el "Oddegutt", el cual la impactó con si bulbo en el costado de Estribor.
Producto de la colisión  el "Oddegutt" sufrió abolladuras de menor importancia en su bulbo y el cacique serios daños en en el costado que dejaron comunicado el mar con su bodega de carga de peces los cuales se fugaron en una cantidad importante al mar.
No se registraron lesionados ni derrames de hidrocarburos al mar.

Three crew members were severely burnt when a thermal heat boiler exploded during firing after maintenance had been carried out. They were medivaced off the ship to hospital in Brisbane.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On Saturday 16 January 2011, the Turkish flagged wooden boat "HASAN REIS" , carrying at least 263 migrants, was travelling to Italy while in intensive blowing winds 6-7 Beaufort, the ship sent out distress signals. The ship was about 30 nautical miles west of Corfu where she started leaking and eventually broke in two. The Dutch ship sail "MOMENTUM SCAN" picked up the survivors and carried them to the port of Corfu, where it was found that 22 passsengers were missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: F/V JONATHAN with 37 persons onboard, sank off Canaron Island in the town of Linapakan, Palawan on January 16. Twenty eight fishermen were rescued while nine others were missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The Chemical tanker, WALDHOF, laden with about 2,400 tons of sulphuric acid, capsized near Sankt Goarshausen at about 0500 on 13 January 2011. Two crew members are missing. Salvors found one dead body inside the WALDHOF after the wreck was stabilized on February 13. The other missing crewmember is thought to have drifted away.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: SAPHIRE II: Unknown/unspecified, SILVER CHORD: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At 1840 on 12 January 2011, the 16.84m prawn trawler Silver Chord collided with the 14.99m prawn trawler Sapphire II.  At the time of the collision, Sapphire II was stopped in the water while her skipper, who was operating single-handed, recovered the vessel’s fishing gear.  Silver Chord was making 5.5 knots as she proceeded towards Stornoway after a day’s fishing.
Sapphire II’s hull was penetrated and the fish hold quickly started to flood. Her skipper reported the accident to the coastguard, and transferred to Silver Chord before Sapphire II sank at about 1850. Silver Chord was also damaged, but was able to return to Stornoway under her own power. There were no injuries.

SOLASStatus: En Kai: SOLAS, EN KAI: SOLAS
Location: Funabashi Central wharf, Chiba Port, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: When a general cargo ship EN KAI was under mooring operation in Funabashi Central Wharf, Chiba Port, Japan, a mooring rope hit a boatswain at her forecastle deck at 10:05, January 11, 2011. The boatswain was taken to the hospital, where he was confirmed dead.

Location: South China sea, 9 miles southwest of Kuala Rajang, Sarawak, Malaysia
SummaryOfEvents: On 11 January 2011 at 0845 hrs (local time), the Malaysian-flagged general cargo ship SOON BEE II capsized and foundered in the South China sea 9 miles southwest of Kuala Rajang, Sarawak, Malaysia after taking in water sustained by a leak in her compartment.  Ten crew members abandoned ship to liferats and reached shore at Kabong, Sarawak on 13 January 2011 and were taken to hospital.   The remaining 8 crew members were reported missing.  MMEA and other ships effected SAR operations.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: South-west off Sado Island, Sado City, Niigata Prefecture, Japan.
SummaryOfEvents:
When the chemical tanker SEIYO, manned with a master and four crew members and loaded with approximately 1,000 tons of vinyl acetate monomer, which had left an anchorage off the Oita Airport, Oita Prefecture and had passed off Rokkosaki, Suzu City (Noto Peninsula), Ishikawa Prefecture, was heading east-northeast toward Akadomari Port (Sado Island), Sado City, Niigata Prefecture on January 9, 2011, she capsized and foundered at around 09:22.

The chief engineer died and the master went missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Le 9 janvier 2011, tôt le matin, le fileyeur Amandhelo quitte son mouillage avec 4 hommes à son bord pour se rendre aux îles de Glénan pour y poser ses filets. Après seulement quelques minutes de route, le patron s’enquiert des prévisions météorologiques. Celles-ci sont très mauvaises pour le lendemain. Le patron décide de retourner à son poste de mouillage. 

Arrivé au niveau de la valise de la Basse La Croix, le fileyeur, ne suit pas l’alignement d’entrée dans le port de Doëlan-sur-Mer et se déporte sur bâbord. La houle, importante, se brise sur les rochers. Le navire talonne puis, poussé par le ressac, vient s’échouer sur la pointe Beg An Tour. Le patron informe aussitôt le CROSS Etel qui engage d’importants moyens nautiques, aériens et terrestres. 

Un des matelots est projeté par-dessus bord. Les trois autres marins regagnent la terre, à la nage pour l’un et par  les rochers pour les deux autres. Le matelot tombé à la mer est récupéré sain et sauf, mais en état d’hypothermie avancé.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Vessel berthed on 8 January port side to in Lyttelton.  as part of the planned maintenance 4 crew were given the task of greasing lifeboat fall wires on No.7 lifeboat.  Commenced work at about 0830, meal break from 1200 to 1300. After meal break 2 crew were greasing davit travelling wires standing on top of the lifeboat using safety harnesses attached to a safety line. at about 1357 requested lifeboat to be lowered a small amount from fully raised position, as lifeboat being lowered forward fall failed at end of davit arm. Lifeboat swung to vertical position suspended on aft fall, safety line broke, 2 crew fell into water.  2 crew were not wearing lifejackets. Alarm raised, emergency boat lowered one crew rescued quickly, second crew could not be found despite extensive search by ship's staff and boats, port authority and rescue services.  Body recovered by divers at 1814 from seabed.

The crew of passenger ro/ro BHARAT SEEMA in port of Kochi have been on strike since January 8. On arrival at Kochi on January 8, a crew member collapsed near the gangway. The vessel's crew claim that no immediate medical treatment was given to the crew member, which led to his death. They began an indefinite strike from January 8.

On 7 January 2011, a line accident occurred on board the FRISIA II. During the casting off manoeuvre at Norddeich, both mooring lines accidentally fell into the water after being removed from the quayside bollard. They then became caught and wound onto the port engine's propeller, which was running backwards. This went unnoticed and the two lines suddenly tightened. Two crew members were occupied with hauling in the lines on the aft manoeuvring station. They were surprised when the mooring lines tightened. At that moment, one of the two men was standing with a leg between one of the mooring bitts and the suddenly tightening line. His leg was crushed and he was seriously injured as a result.

At about 0650 hours on January 7, while the general cargo YUN XING, in ballast was lying anchored at Southern harbour, Busan, a fire was noted in the accomodation space and a coast guard fire boat arrived and commenced fire fighting. The fire was controlled at about 0850, same day. Four out of a total of nine crewmembers were found dead and the surviving crew were investigated by the Coast Guard. The Coast Guard officials suspected that the blaze might have been caused by a short-circuit. One rescued seaman told investigators that the fire had started around the first floor kitchen. The Coast Guard officials believed that smoke had hampered a quick evacuation of the sailors who were sleeping at the time of the fire. The bodies were found in the first floor kitchen and a second floor cabin.

A Cambadian flag fishing vessel "PARTNYOR" with about 12 people on board went missing after sending a distress signal that it was sinking off Russia's Pacific coast on January 7. The search by air, sea and land found no sign of the vessel and had to abandon their search on January 10 due to the stormy weather and darkness. There was no ice in that part of the sea.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: At 12:48 hrs on 6 January 2011, a fisherman on board the 8.24 metres Blue Angel was dragged overboard when his leg became caught in the back rope of a fleet of creels that was being shot over the stern. He was submerged for several minutes at depth of up to 40 metres before the two remaining crewmen managed to recover him onboard and administer first-aid. A coastguard helicopter arrived on scene swiftly and transferred the fisherman to hospital where he made a full recovery.

On January 5, the Carnival Cruise ship LIBERTY OF THE SEAS experienced passenger overboard 6 miles off Turneffe Island in Belize. The passenger of 21-year-old was revealed by the ship's surveillance camera to have jumped off the twelfth deck of the vessel.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: After main engine problem and electrical problems, the vessel fixed both items and continue sailing towards Basra, Iraq. On January 4, 2011 at approx 15:00 smoke was observed coming out from Hold NO.1.   After taking preventive measures to contain the fire and avoid spreading, the fire quickly spread throughout the vessel.  The Master ordered abandon of the ship after the fire was not able to be contained.  There were not any crew fatality. The vessel was total loss.

Location: At the Entrance to Ardglass Harbour
SummaryOfEvents: At 17:55 hours, on 3 January 2011, the stern prawn trawler Karen grounded at the entrance to Ardgrass Harbour. Resulting damage to the ship’s forefoot caused her to take water forward. However, the collision bulkhead held and the skipper left the engine running ahead to reduce the risk of the ship foundering. The crew donned their lifejackets and successfully launched the liferaft, but before they were forced to evacuate the ship they were rescued by the Portaferry inshore lifeboat (ILB). One crewman suffered minor bruising to ribs. Karen was refloated and manoeuvred alongside later that evening.

Location: 30 yards from a wharf in Galilee, R. I.
SummaryOfEvents: On 3 January 2011, the F/V HEATHER LYNNE II sank in just 12 feet of water some 30 yards from a public wharf in Galilee, R. I. No injuries were reported in this incident.

The vessel, while transiting open sea, allegedly collided into Chinese flagged fishing boat, LUDONGGANGYU. ZIM SHEKOU, transiting an area heavily trafficked with fishing boats, exercised particular care navigating and crew members observed no collision with any vessel in that area. However, allegations provide that ZIM SHEKOU collided into the fishing boat which left 10 of the 11 crew members missing.

On the 2nd of January 2011, MV “SMARAGD”, lying at Boma anchorage, Democratic Republic of Congo, lost a seaman overboard during outboard work on the vessels stern.
Two deck ratings were assigned to carry out paint work on the stern of MV “SMARAGD”. According to present findings and statements all preparations were made in accordance with on board ISM and both crew members were properly briefed.
After interrupting the maintenance work for the afternoon coffee break, the deceased seaman climbed overboard onto the rigged bosun stage to continue, not having waited to be secured by a second man, slipped off the stage and not being able to hold himself was taken away by the strong current.
Combined efforts by crew, on scene vessels and local authorities to save or recover the seaman were without positive outcome. 

This occupational accident which resulted in the death of a seafarer occurred directly in connection with the operation of a ship and thus has to be classified to having been a very serious marine casualty. Consequently, a marine safety investigation will be conducted.
